weatherOverview: Due to its elevation and protected location beneath steep cliff walls, the campground at Dog Canyon has cooler temperatures in the summer and is sheltered from strong gusty winds in the winter and spring.

accessibility.internetInfo: Free WiFi is available for visitors at the Dog Canyon Ranger Station. The WiFi is available 24 hrs a day and does not require a password.
accessibility.cellPhoneInfo: There is no cell phone reception in the Dog Canyon area.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Wood and charcoal fires are not allowed year round. All cooking must be done with contained fuel stoves.

name: Dorst Creek Campground
description: Ten miles (16 km) from the Giant Forest, Dorst Creek Campground rests under open stands of evergreen trees at an elevation of 6,800 feet (2,073 m). This centrally-located campground is well situated for those exploring both parks. In the summer, catch the Sequoia Shuttle from the campground for easy travel to Lodgepole and Giant Forest. The trail to the Muir Grove of giant sequoias begins here.
reservationInfo: Reservations usually available mid June through early September. We are not accepting reservation in 2022 due to the campground closure associated with impacts from the KNP Fire and the need to remove hazard trees.
regulationsOverview: Black bears are active in this area. Food and scented items must be stored properly to protect bears and other wildlife. When you arrive at the campground, be prepared to store all food and scented items in metal food-storage boxes provided at each site. http://www.nps.gov/seki/planyourvisit/bears.htm

fees.description: This fee is valid for up to six people at a single tent or RV site per night.
fees.title: Tent or RV Site

fees.description: These group sites accommodate from 12 to 25 people. The fee is charged per night.
fees.title: Group Sites A & B

fees.description: This group site accommodates from 12 - 40 people. The fee is charged per night.
fees.title: Groups Site C

fees.description: This group site accommodates from 12-50 people. The fee is charged per night.
fees.title: Group Site D

directionsOverview: From either main park entrance, take the Generals Highway to Dorst Creek Campground. If you're approaching from the South, the entrance will be on your left. If you're approaching from the North, it will be out your right.

operatingHours.description:
Dorst Creek Campground usually opens in mid June and closes on Labor Day weekend.

Due to impacts from the KNP Fire and the need to remove hazard trees to make the campground safe, Dorst Creek Campground will be closed through summer 2022. We're hoping that the campground can reopen for the 2023 season.
operatingHours.name: Dorst Creek Campground

images.altText: An entrance sign reading "Dorst Creek Campground" beside a road

images.caption: Dorst Creek Campground sites are well suited for recreational vehicles.

weatherOverview: This campground is at 6,800 feet (2,073 m). Summers are usually warm and sunny, however the weather can change at any time. Be prepared for three-season camping, even in summer.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: The campground is fully paved, and relatively flat and level. The path to the amphitheater is very steep and would be difficult to reach by wheelchair.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: In summer, fire restrictions may be in effect if conditions are dry, even at higher-elevation campgrounds. When fire danger is very high, wood and charcoal fires (including campfires in fire rings and wood-burning stoves) may be prohibited. Check current fire restrictions online or at park bulletin boards before you camp.
accessibility.rvInfo: Dorst Creek Campground has sites for RVs and trailers of nearly any length, including pull-through sites. When making reservations, you can filter available sites by entering the length of your RV. A dump station is available at the campground. Generators are allowed from 8 to 11 am and from 5 to 8 pm.
accessibility.additionalInfo: A pay telephone, flush toilets, ranger programs offered in the summer at the amphitheater, and free Sequoia Shuttle to Giant Forest with a stop in the campground.
accessibility.adaInfo: Campsites 6, 11, 172175, 177, and 180 are designated accessible. These sites feature paved accessible parking, level tent pads, grills, picnic tables, and access paths to campground facilities.

name: Dosewallips Campground (Walk-In Only)
description: Perfect for secluded tent camping. The access road is washed out 6.5 miles from the campground and it is not vehicle accessible.
reservationInfo: First come, first served.

fees.description: $15 per night.
fees.title: Dosewallips Campground (Walk-In Only)

directionsOverview: Dosewallips Campground is accessible off the Dosewallips Rd. This can been accessed from Highway 101. The Dosewallips road is washed-out outside the Olympic National Park boundary, 6.5 miles from the campground and cannot be traversed with a vehicle. All campers must hike past the wash-out and walk into the campground.

operatingHours.description: This campground is only accessible by foot.
operatingHours.name: Dosewallips Campground (Walk-In Only)

images.title: Dosewallips Campground
images.altText: Tent in Campsite
images.caption: Campsite in Dosewallips Camground

weatherOverview: Weather and conditions at Olympic can change quickly. For a safe and enjoyable trip, check road, campground, weather, and trail conditions before your visit. Current road, campground, and weather information is also available by calling (360) 565-3131 or visiting the park website at http://www.nps.gov/olym/planyourvisit/current-conditions.htm

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Not wheelchair accessible.
accessibility.internetInfo: No internet access.
accessibility.cellPhoneInfo: Limited to no cell phone service.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires and stoves allowed. Fires must be in designated fire grates at all times. Always check for any fire bans due to dry or hazardous conditions before your visit.
accessibility.rvInfo: Walk-in Campground only. Trailers, RVs, or vehicles are not permitted.
accessibility.adaInfo: The Dosewallips road is washed-out outside the park boundary, 6.5 miles from the campground and cannot be traversed with a vehicle. All campers must hike past the wash-out and walk into the campground. No wheelchair accessibility.

name: Doughton Park Campground
description: Doughton Park Campground is nestled in a landscape of mountains and open meadows. Explore the history of early settlers, enjoy spectacular shows of flame azalea and rhododendron, stretch your legs on area hiking trails, and view wildlife such as white-tailed deer, raccoons, red and gray foxes, and bobcats. Originally known as The Bluffs, this area is now part of the 7000-acre Doughton Park, named in honor of Congressman Robert Doughton, a long-time advocate and supporter of the Blue Ridge Parkway.
reservationInfo: Campsites are available on a first-come, first-served basis. In addition, advance reservations can be made for some campsites up to six months in advance by visiting www.recreation.gov or by calling (877) 444-6777.

fees.description: Per night charge for campsites is posted in each campground and available at www.nps.gov/blri. Holders of the Interagency Senior, Access, Golden Age, or Golden Access passes are entitled to a 50% discount on the base fee of the site physically occupied by the pass holder. Passes can be obtained at all campgrounds.
fees.title: Doughton Park Campground Fee

fees.description: Campsite maximum 20 people, minimum 12 people. Pass holder discounts do not apply.
fees.title: Group Campsites

directionsOverview: GPS Info. (Latitude, Longitude): 36.42889, -81.15444 3625'44"N, 819'16"W Campground is located at Parkway Milepost 239.2 in North Carolina.

operatingHours.description:
Campground open from May through October each year. Visit the parkway's website at 
https://www.nps.gov/blri/planyourvisit/hours.htm for this year's dates.

Campground kiosk open 9:30 AM- 6:00 PM daily from May through October.
operatingHours.name: Doughton Park Campground

images.caption: In summer, wildflowers bloom in the fields around Doughton Park

images.title: Doughton Park Campsite

images.caption: A secluded campsite on the B-loop in Doughton Park Campground

images.title: Blue Ridge Music Center

weatherOverview: The Parkway varies in elevation from under 650 feet at Virginia's James River to over 6,000 feet near Mount Pisgah in North Carolina. Weather can vary tremendously. Higher elevations can be cloudy and foggy while lower elevations are clear. Temperatures along the Parkway are often cooler than in surrounding foothills. Carry a jacket or blanket and emergency supplies in the car. Be aware of changing weather conditions and approaching weather systems, as summer heat can bring afternoon thunderstorms.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Two accessible campsites located adjacent to an accessible restroom.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Invasive insects and diseases that live in firewood are a growing threat to forests along the Blue Ridge Parkway and the surrounding region. Tree-killing insects and diseases can hitch-hike hundreds of miles on firewood when people bring wood into campgrounds. Counties in many states have federal or state quarantines in place which prohibit moving firewood. These quarantines were issued to prevent the spread of emerald ash borer, Asian long-horn beetle, gypsy moth, and thousand cankers disease. Federal and state regulations prohibit visitors from bringing firewood to the park from these counties. See https://www.nps.gov/blri/planyourvisit/firewood-quarantine-by-state.htm for a list of quarantined counties.
accessibility.rvInfo: The campground has a dump station and potable water, but NO water or electric hookups.
accessibility.additionalInfo: Area hiking trails: Bluff Mountain, Fodder Stack
accessibility.adaInfo: Campground has two accessible campsites, each with accessible grill and picnic table. Restrooms with flush toilets, drinking water, walkways are accessible. No electric hookups or showers in campground.

name: Douglas Spring
description: - 4,800 feet elevation - 3 campsites (6 people max per site)

name: Dry Creek Group Campground
description: Dry Creek Group Campground includes two large campsites. Each site is primitive and may be reserved for groups of up to 50 people (20 people minimum). The campsites are located within oak woodland on a peninsula surrounded on three sides by Whiskeytown Lake. The primitive campground is located near Brandy Creek Marina.
audioDescription: The campground is located on a peninsula where John F. Kennedy Memorial Drive ends on the south side of Whiskeytown Lake. The campground is in a park-like setting of oak woodland, surrounded on three sides by lakeshore. There are two group sites, each able to accommodate up to 50 people. Sites include picnic tables, a fire ring with a grill, a larger grill and several bear-resistant storage lockers. Additional picnic tables are located some distance away from the group sites. There are two ADA accessible vault-style restroom facilities in the campground.
reservationInfo: Reservations are required for Dry Creek Group Campground and can be made up to six months in advance. In 2021, the campground is open June 1st to October 31st. The fee is $80 per site per night. Minimum of 20 people per site, maximum of 50 people per site. To make a reservation, follow the URL link or call 1-877-444-6777.
regulationsOverview: * Check-in time is 1:00 pm and check-out time is noon. * Reservations are required * The fee is $80.00 per site per night with a minimum of 20 and a maximum of 50 campers per site. Larger groups may reserve both sites for a total of 100 campers. * Camping is limited to an aggregate of 14 days between May 15 and September 15 (inclusive) and no more than 30 days per person per calendar year. No period of stay of 30 days may be succeeded by any period of stay with less than a 7-day break.

fees.description: Dry Creek Group Camp costs $80 per night and is available through reservation only.
fees.title: Dry Creek Group Camp fee

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: This campground features unpaved ground with gentle slopes towards the middle, becoming much steeper as you near the water. Some picnic tables are wheelchair accessible. Two vault toilet restrooms are accessible.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Campfires are allowed in designated fire rings unless fire restrictions are in effect. The use of gas lanterns & stoves are allowed unless current fire restrictions prohibit them. Do not leave campfires unattended. Always make sure that your fire is completely extinguished before you leave your campsite or before you go to sleep for the night.
accessibility.rvInfo: RVs and trailers are not allowed at Dry Creek Group Camp.
accessibility.adaInfo: This campground features unpaved ground with gentle slopes towards the middle, becoming much steeper as you near the water. Some picnic tables are wheelchair accessible. Two vault toilet restrooms are accessible.
accessRoads: Unpaved Roads - All vehicles OK in good weather

name: Dry Gulch Campground
description: Dry Gulch Campground is located 17 miles west of Gunnison just north of U.S. Highway 50. The campground is shaded by large cottonwood trees and can accommodate tents or medium sized RVs. All sites are first-come first-served. A horse corral is available. Elevation: 7560 feet

fees.description: $16.00 per night ($8.00 per night with Interagency Senior/Access Pass)
fees.title: Dry Gulch Campground

operatingHours.description: Typically open May to mid-October. The campground is open as long as the road is passable.

weatherOverview: Weather can vary greatly throughout the day. Summer daytime temperatures range between 50 to 90F (10 to 32C), nights 40 to 60F (4 to 15C). Precipitation is minimal, but afternoon thunderstorms and strong winds are common during the summer.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Unpaved surfaces.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires in provided grates are allowed. Camp stoves are also allowed.
accessibility.rvInfo: Parking areas at each campsite vary from 20-35 feet in length.
accessibility.adaInfo: Unpaved surfaces.
accessRoads: Unpaved Roads - All vehicles OK in good weather

name: Duck Harbor Campground
description: Duck Harbor Campground is located on Isle au Haut, a rugged island off the coast of Stonington, Maine. This campground has five sites with lean-to shelters and is a great launch point for paddling excursions. Remote and inaccessible to automobiles, Isle au Haut is linked to the mainland by mailboat.
audioDescription: Five wood lean-to shelters, three-sided with roof and floor. Dimensions are 8' tall, 8' deep, and 12.5' wide. Sites have fire rings and picnic tables. The campground has a composting vault toilet and a hand pump for water located 1,600 feet from shelters.
reservationInfo: Reservations are required to camp at Duck Harbor Campground. Reservations are available 7 months in advance of the reservation date.
regulationsOverview: No pets allowed in the campground. Maximum length of stay is three nights. Campers are limited to one stay per calendar year. Six people are permitted per campsite. All trash must be carried out. Please do not bring your own firewood to reduce the spread of non-native insects. Check-in time and check-out time is 11:00am All campsites must be reserved. Camping without a reservation is prohibited. Arriving Late? You must arrive at your campsite before 11:00am check-out time on the day after your scheduled arrival date. If you cannot arrive by that time, you must call (207) 335-5551 or you will be marked a No Show and incur fees. Quiet hours are from 10 p.m. to 8 a.m. Generator use is prohibited.

fees.description:
Fee/per night
maximum number of people: 6
fees.title: Tent/Shelter Non-Electric

directionsOverview: Isle au Haut and Duck Harbor Campground are inaccessible by car. Campers may boat in to Duck Harbor, or take the Isle au Haut mailboat from Stonington. Check with the Isle au Haut Boat Services for boat schedule. Boat transportation may be limited especially at the beginning and end of the season.

addresses.line1: Acadia National Park, Attn: Duck Harbor Campground, PO Box 177
Acadia National Park, Attn: Duck Harbor Campground, PO Box 177

images.title: Isle au Haut Wayfinding Junction
images.altText: A park ranger and three other adults stand by a wood wayside with area information and directions
images.caption: You can paddle to your site, or walk in from this trailhead.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Isle au Haut and Duck Harbor Campground are not wheelchair-accessible. Terrain is rocky and uneven, and trails are narrow.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Each site has a fire ring. Dead and downed wood may be collected near the campground. Please do not bring your own firewood to reduce the spread of non-native insects.
accessibility.rvInfo: RVs and trailers are not allowed in Duck Harbor Campground.
accessibility.additionalInfo: There is a ranger station 4 miles from the campground but only 0.3 miles from the Isle au Haut Town Landing. The ranger station is open mid-April to mid-October, when there are rangers on Isle au Haut for the season. While the rangers are typically out in the field and not at the ranger station during most of the day, the lobby remains open, allowing visitors access to maps, reading material, water, and the only public restroom in town. There is a small, traditional village near the Isle au Haut Town Landing where one can find a general store, seasonal gift shop, a seasonal food shack, and post office.
accessibility.adaInfo: Duck Harbor Campground and facilities are not accessible. Terrain is uneven, and shelters have a stepped entrance.

description: No overnight camping allowed. Dump Station is for dumping garbage and RV sewage.

accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Gas stoves are permitted. Fires may only be built in provided metal fire rings. Fires must be extinguished when not attended. Only dead wood on the ground may be collected for use as fuel for campfires within the park. Standing trees or shrubs, alive or dead, and trees/shrubs that are still attached to the ground may not be collected. Chainsaw use is prohibited without a permit. Collection of Bristlecone Pine wood and any wood above 10,000 feet is not allowed. Check for local fire bans.

name: Dunbar Group Site
description: The Dunbar Group Site holds up to 30 people and is located less than 500 feet from the beach. The site overlooks the Great Marsh and Lake Michigan. Parking and restrooms are located in the Dunbar Beach parking lot, 400 feet from the site.
reservationInfo: Reservations can be made up to 6-months in advance. Reservations are made through recreation.gov.
regulationsOverview: Stays are limited to 14 days in a 30-day period. Quiet hours are daily, 10:00 pm to 6:00 am. Please be considerate of others. A maximum of 30 people on the site. Bikes can be walked to the tent sites. Pets must be attended and on a leash of 6 foot or less. Prohibited Activities Driving over 15 MPH on campground roads Bicycles / vehicles off of paved roads Campfires outside of the provided grates Damaging of trees especially cutting or driving nails in trees Digging / leveling the campsite Bathing / washing at water outlets Disturbing / hunting / capturing wildlife or plants Fireworks See campground for a complete list of regulations

fees.description: The group site rate is valid for up to 30 people in 10 tents.  There are no discounts on group sites.
fees.title: Group Site Rate

directionsOverview: From Broadway and Lake Front Drive, head west on Lake Front Drive. At the stop sign at Dunbar Ave turn south. The parking lot is at the top of the hill on the west side of the road.

operatingHours.description: Open April 1 through October 31.
operatingHours.name: Dunbar Group Site

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: The site is not wheelchair accessible.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: All fires must be made in the provided fire ring. Please do not collect sticks for fires.

accessibility.adaInfo: There is a large hill with uneven terrain to walk up to get to the group site. The site is grass covered. Restrooms are located downhill in the parking lot.

name: Duncan Bay Campground
description: Duncan Bay Campground is located on the west end of Duncan Bay, on the northeast end of Isle Royale National Park. Boats can stay overnight at dock. Stay Limit: 3 nights from June 2  Labor Day annually. Shelters: 2 Depth at dock (normal conditions): 6 Access: Canoe/kayak/private boat
audioDescription: Duncan Bay Campground is located on the west end of Duncan Bay, on the northeast end of Isle Royale National Park. Consecutive night stay limit is three nights from June 1  Labor Day annually. One individual tent site, two shelter sites, and vault toilet are available. Boats are permitted to stay overnight at the dock. Campground is accessible by canoe/kayak/private boat.
reservationInfo: Individual tent sites and shelters are first come, first serve.
regulationsOverview: All park visitors pay an entrance fee. Campfire rings and standing grills provided. Dogs, cats, and other pets are not allowed. Quiet hours are from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. EDT/ 9:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. CDT. Fishing licenses are not required for inland lakes and streams on the island. However, Michigan size, season, and possession limits still apply. Only barbless hooks and artificial lures and flies may be used on inland lakes and streams. A State of Michigan fishing license is required to fish in the waters of Lake Superior.

fees.description: No fee for small-party camping. A free overnight permit is required.
fees.title: Small-party Camping (6 people or less)

weatherOverview: Isle Royale National Park is a remote archipelago in the middle of Lake Superior. To make the most of your visit, it is necessary that you plan ahead and prepare. Be aware that many services and items that are available on the mainland are not available at Isle Royale. Due to the unpredictable waters of Lake Superior and its effect on island weather, be prepared for any and all weather conditions.

accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Grills at each individual tent site. Otherwise, self-contained stoves only.
accessibility.rvInfo: No RV/Trailer access.

name: Duncan Narrows Campground
description: Duncan Narrows Campground is located in the narrows of Duncan Bay on the northeast end of Isle Royale National Park. Boats can stay overnight at dock. audioDescription: Duncan Narrows Campground is located in the narrows of Duncan Bay on the northeast end of Isle Royale National Park. There is one individual tent site and two shelters. Normal conditions at the dock are 6. Boats are permitted to stay overnight at the dock. Access available to canoe/kayak/private boat.
reservationInfo: Individual tent sites and shelters first come, first serve.
regulationsOverview: All park visitors pay an entrance fee. Campfire rings or standing grills provided. Dogs, cats, and other pets are not allowed. Quiet hours are from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. EDT/ 9:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. CDT. Fishing licenses are not required for inland lakes and streams on the island. However, Michigan size, season, and possession limits still apply. Only barbless hooks and artificial lures and flies may be used on inland lakes and streams. A State of Michigan fishing license is required to fish in the waters of Lake Superior.

Be aware that many services and items that are available on the mainland are not available at Isle Royale. Due to the unpredictable waters of Lake Superior and its effect on island weather, be prepared for any and all weather conditions.

name: Dundo Group Campground
description: Dundo Group Campground (mile 83.7) is a small, beautiful campground located in the southern part of Shenandoah National Park that offers group campsites, only. The Appalachian Trail passes through the campground. All sites include fire rings and picnic tables.
audioDescription: Three large campsites located in the back of a picnic ground. A one-lane, one-way road travels counter-clockwise in a loop to access the sites. Site 1 is to the left of the road and is the first site. Sites 2 and 3 are down the road and around a corner, on the right and situated next to one another.
reservationInfo: Reservations for Dundo Group Campground may be made up to one year in advance, although you may also inquire about availability on a night-by-night basis at Loft Mountain Campground (mile 79.5). Reservations are highly recommended, especially on weekends and holidays.
regulationsOverview: Check-ins for Dundo Group Campground are done at Loft Mountain Campground, approximately 3 miles north on Skyline Drive (mile 79.5). Stays are limited to 30 consecutive nights per year. Checkout time is noon. Camping fees must be paid within one (1) hour of occupying a site. Be sure to clip your camping pass to your site post to show occupancy. Quiet hours are from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m. All generators are prohibited. Bear, deer, raccoons, and skunks are year-round residents of Shenandoah. Food, garbage, equipment used to prepare or store food, and all scented items must be kept in a locked vehicle or storage locker when not being actively used. It is illegal to feed or disturb wildlife.

emailAddresses.description: We get a large number of e-mail inquiries, and e-mails are not answered on weekends. Please allow one week for a reply.

fees.description: Dundo Group Campground has three nonelectric group sites. Each group site can accommodate 7-20 people.
fees.title: Group Campsite (Nonelectric)

directionsOverview: From Richmond, Virginia (via Rockfish Gap): travel west on Interstate 64 for approximately 87 miles, then take exit 99 and follow signs to Shenandoah National Park and Skyline Drive. Once on the Skyline Drive, head north approximately 20 miles to mile 83.7, where you will arrive at Dundo Group Campground/Picnic area.

operatingHours.description: Dundo Group Campground is open during the late spring, summer, and fall. Opening and closing dates vary from year to year and are subject to change at any time. Camping is NOT permitted in the campgrounds when they are closed.
operatingHours.name: Dundo Group Campground

images.title: Dundo Group Campground
images.altText: Several large tents sit behind a man who is standing at a table in a campground.
images.caption: Dundo Group Campground offers a great opportunity to enjoy Shenandoah with friends and family.

weatherOverview: Shenandoah National Park has four very distinct seasons. Spring typically brings mild temperatures, rain, and wildflowers. Summer brings lush green forests, but can be hot and very humid. Fall follows with cooler temperatures and spectacular fall foliage. Winter can bring snow and ice. The mountain is usually 10F cooler than the valley below. Always check the forecast, dress in layers, and be prepared.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: There are no wheelchair accessible sites, showers, or laundy facilities available at Dundo Group Campground.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: To help slow the spread of the emerald ash borer, visitors must only use USDA-certified firewood (signified by the USDA stamp on packaging), which can be purchased in the Park. Dead wood may also be used if it is gathered from the ground in the Park; do not cut, saw, or break any standing trees, dead or alive, for firewood. Fires are only allowed in Park-provided fire grates. You must fully extinguish your fire before leaving the area, even for a short amount of time. To do this, simply douse the fire with water and stir with a stick. Repeat this until you no longer feel warmth coming from the fire grate. Camping and backpacking stoves are permitted, but the use of charcoal grills is prohibited.
accessibility.rvInfo: All RVs and trailers are prohibited at Dundo Group Campground.
accessibility.adaInfo: There are no accessible sites, showers, or laundy facilities available at Dundo Group Campground.

name: Dunewood Campground
description: Campground consists of two loops containing 66 camp-sites (53 conventional drive-in sites and 13 walk/carry-in sites). Four sites are wheelchair accessible (numbers 15, 30, 41 and 55). Each loop has modern restrooms and hot/cold showers. Some sites have limited recreational vehicle length. Convenience stores and a gas station are located 1/4 mile north of the campground at the intersection of U.S. Highway 12 and Broadway Ave. in the town of Beverly Shores. Campground closed during winter, Nov 2 - Mar 31.
reservationInfo: All campsites are reserved on Recreation.gov. Check-out time is noon. New "check-ins" cannot occupy your site until noon, unless the site is vacant.
regulationsOverview: Stays are limited to 14 days in a 30-day period. Quiet hours are daily, 10:00 pm to 6:00 am. Please be considerate of others. All tents and equipment must be set up on the camping pad. A maximum of 8 people per site. All vehicles and RV campers must remain completely on the pavement. Bikes can be walked to the tent sites. Pets must be attended and on a leash of 6 foot or less. Prohibited Activities Driving over 15 MPH on campground roads Bicycles / vehicles off of paved roads Campfires outside of the provided grates Damaging of trees especially cutting or driving nails in trees Digging / leveling the campsite Bathing / washing at water outlets Disturbing / hunting / capturing wildlife or plants Fireworks See campground for a complete list of regulations

fees.description: $25.00 per night.
fees.title: Standard Night Fee

fees.description: The Access Pass provides a 50% each night.
fees.title: Access Pass

fees.title: Senior Pass

Turn left onto Golf Wood Rd

operatingHours.description: Open April 1 through October 31.

weatherOverview: On average, the warmest month is July and the highest recorded temperature was 105F in 1934. The coolest month is January, with the lowest recorded temperature of -25F in 1985. June sees the most precipitation with an average rainfall of 4.66 Inches.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Most sites are packed gravel. Accessible sites 15,30,41, and 55 are paved. Some walk-in sites have stairs.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires must be in camping rings only. Camping stoves are permitted.
accessibility.rvInfo: All site information is available on the following webpage: https://www.recreation.gov/camping/campgrounds/258887 RVs and Trailers must fit on site.
accessibility.adaInfo: The campground loop is paced. Sites 15, 30, 41, and 55 are accessible. Facilities, located in the center of both loops, are also accessible.

name: Dyea Campground
description: The Dyea Campground is located 9 miles from Skagway. Nestled in the trees along the banks of the Taiya River with limited amenities, the Dyea Campground is a restful place from busy town. The campground is within a short drive or bike ride of the historic townsite of Dyea and a half mile from the Chilkoot Trailhead. The campground is monitored by National Park Service rangers and is open when free of snow.
reservationInfo: Reservations are not taken for this campground. Sites fill on a first-come, first-served basis.
regulationsOverview: Camping is permitted only in designated areas. Camping without a permit is prohibited. The superintendent may establish permit terms and conditions. Failure to comply with permit terms and conditions is prohibited. Camping at the Dyea Campground for more than 14 days in a calendar year is prohibited. Vehicles over 26 feet are restricted from travel across federal lands in Dyea (including the campground), except as otherwise specifically approved in advance by the Superintendent.

fees.description: This is the nightly cost for each site regardless of RV, tent, group, or walk-in.
fees.title: Campsite Fee

directionsOverview: The Dyea Campground is located 9 miles from Skagway and .5 miles from the the Chilkoot trailhead.

operatingHours.description: Campground is open 24 hours a day during summer months.
operatingHours.name: Dyea Campground

weatherOverview: This campground is at the end of Lynn Canal and can experience high winds and variable conditions. Be prepared for three-season camping, even in summer.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Campground surfaces are mostly flat, unpaved gravel, but free of large rocks. Several sites have wheelchair accessible picnic tables.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires may be made only in established fire rings.
accessibility.rvInfo: Large RVs and trailers may have difficulty crossing the bridge over the Taiya River between the Dyea campground and Dyea townsite.
accessibility.adaInfo: Campground surfaces are mostly flat, unpaved gravel, but free of large rocks. Several sites have wheelchair accessible picnic tables.
accessRoads: Unpaved Roads - All vehicles OK in good weather

name: East Chickenbone Campground
description: An inland campground located on the east end of Chickenbone Lake, off of the East Chickenbone Trail. No boater access. Canoe/kayak access using 1.2 mile portage from McCargoe Cove or 0.2 mile portage from Lake Livermore. Be aware that the campground is not on the shoreline - West Chickenbone Campground is more accessible for watercraft. Stay Limit: 2 nights from June 1  Labor Day annually. Access: Foot/canoe/kayak
audioDescription: East Chickenbone Campground located on the east end of Chickenbone Lake, off of the East Chickenbone Trail. This backcountry campground includes three individual tent sties and one group site. There is no boater access. Canoe/kayak access using 1.2 mile portage from McCargoe Cove or .2 mile portage from Lake Livermore. This campground is not on the shoreline but offers a forest experience.
reservationInfo: Individual tent site first come, first serve. Group site needs to be reserved in advance.
regulationsOverview: All park visitors pay an entrance fee. Self-contained stoves only. Dogs, cats, and other pets are not allowed. Quiet hours are from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. EDT/ 9:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. CDT. Fishing licenses are not required for inland lakes and streams on the island. However, Michigan size, season, and possession limits still apply. Only barbless hooks and artificial lures and flies may be used on inland lakes and streams. A State of Michigan fishing license is required to fish in the waters of Lake Superior.

fees.description: No fee for small-party camping. A free overnight permit is required.
fees.title: Small-party Camping (6 people or less)

fees.description: 1 Group Site by advanced reservation only. All parties of 7 or more must submit group permit requests through the park's online request system. The fee is a per permit cost for each party within a group of 7 or more.
fees.title: Group Tent Site

directionsOverview: The East Chickenbone Campground is located on the east end of Chickenbone Lake, off of the East Chickenbone Lake Campground.

operatingHours.description: The campground is open from April 16 - October 31 (the park operating season) annually, 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: East Chickenbone Campground

images.title: View of Chickenbone Lake from the East Lake Chickenbone Trail

images.caption: The East Lake Chickenbone Trail travels along Chickenbone Lake for part of the trail.

images.title: East Chickenbone Campground Tent Site

images.caption: Tent in East Chickenbone Campground during fall.

weatherOverview: Isle Royale National Park is a remote archipelago in the middle of Lake Superior. To make the most of your visit, it is necessary that you plan ahead and prepare. Be aware that many services and items that are available on the mainland are not available at Isle Royale. Due to the unpredictable waters of Lake Superior and its effect on island weather, be prepared for any and all weather conditions.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Not wheelchair accessible.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Self-contained stoves only.
accessibility.rvInfo: No RV/Trailer access.
accessibility.adaInfo: Uneven, rough terrain throughout campground. Facilities are not accessible.

name: East Elk Creek Group Campground
description: East Elk Creek is a group campsite that can accommodate a total of 50 people. The site is located 16.5 miles west of Gunnison just north of U.S. Highway 50. The campsites are located under large Cottonwood trees and space is available for tents or RVs. Elevation: 7535 feet
reservationInfo: Reservations are required and must be made 3 days in advance.

fees.description: 50 people maximum.
fees.title: East Elk Creek Group Campground 1

directionsOverview: From Gunnison, travel 16.5 miles west on U.S. Highway 50. The campground is on the north side of the highway.

operatingHours.description: Open approximately May to mid-October.
operatingHours.name: East Elk Creek Group Campground

images.caption: The campground is shaded by Cottonwood trees.

weatherOverview: Weather can vary greatly throughout the day. Summer daytime temperatures range between 50 to 90F (10 to 32C), nights 40 to 60F (4 to 15C). Precipitation is minimal, but afternoon thunderstorms and strong winds are common during the summer.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Unpaved surfaces only.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Campfires are allowed in the grates provided. Campstoves are allowed.
accessibility.rvInfo: Small to medium RVs can be parked in the parking area.
accessibility.adaInfo: No accessible campsites.
accessRoads: Unpaved Roads - All vehicles OK in good weather

name: East Portal Campground
description: The East Portal Campground is located within Curecanti National Recreation Area, but is adjacent to and only accessible from Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park, which has a $30 entrance fee. The campground is located at the bottom of the canyon, along the Gunnison River. It is a small campground shaded by box elder trees. East Portal is closed in winter, when the Bureau of Reclamation closes the East Portal Road. Elevation: 6526 feet
reservationInfo: East Portal Campground sites cannot be reserved.

operatingHours.description: Campground is open 24 hours in the summer. Check out time is 1 pm.  The campground is typically open May to mid-October, weather permitting, and when the East Portal road is open. Water is typically available mid-May to mid-September (after the last frost of spring and the first frost of fall).
operatingHours.name: East Portal Campground

images.title: East Portal Campground  - Sites with vehicle access
images.altText: East Portal Campground  - Sites with vehicle access
images.caption: Five out of the fifteen sites have vehicle access.

images.title: East Portal Campground - Walk-in sites
images.altText: East Portal Campground - Walk-in sites
images.caption: Ten of the 15 sites are walk-in tent sites.

weatherOverview: This Campground is at the bottom of Black Canyon near the Gunnison River, at 6,526 feet in elevation. Weather can rapidly change from warm and sunny to cold and rainy or snowy. Be prepared for 3-season camping, even in summer. Temperature range can vary 30 degrees or more throughout the day and night.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: The campground is not wheelchair accessible.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are permitted only in the designated fire rings, and only as long as there are no burn bans or dangerous fire weather.
accessibility.rvInfo: Vehicles 22 feet and over in length are not allowed on the East Portal Road and, therefore, not allowed in the campground.
accessibility.adaInfo: East Portal campground is not ADA accessible. The campground road and parking areas are all gravel and all campsites are unimproved ground. 5 campsites have parking spaces adjacent to the site; 10 campsites are walk-in and require walking down steps from the parking area to the sites. Access to pit toilets and water is on compacted dirt paths.

name: East Portal Campground
description: The East Portal Campground is located within Curecanti National Recreation Area, but is adjacent to and only accessible from Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park, where the entrance fee is $30. The campground is located at the bottom of the canyon, along the Gunnison River. It is a small campground shaded by box elder trees. East Portal is closed in winter, when the Bureau of Reclamation closes the East Portal Road. Elevation: 6526 feet
reservationInfo: East Portal Campground sites cannot be reserved.
regulationsOverview: -Camp only in designated sites. -Maximum occupancy: 8 people, 2 vehicles per campsite. -Check In/ Out Time: 1 pm -Pets must be leashed at all times. -Properly extinguish fires. Do not leave fires unattended. -Use bear boxes for any scented items, food, etc. -Stay is limited to 14 consecutive nights for a total of 30 days within a calendar year.

fees.description: $16.00 per night ($8.00 per night with Interagency Senior/Access Pass)
fees.title: East Portal Campground

directionsOverview: From Montrose, take Hwy 50 east. After about 6 miles turn left onto Hwy 347 and follow it for 6 miles. Hwy 347 turns into the South Rim Drive of Black Canyon National Park. Just past the parks entrance station, turn right into East Portal. Follow the road 5 miles to the base of the canyon and turn left at the T-Junction. The Campground is just past the ranger station.

operatingHours.description: Campground is open 24 hours in the summer. Check out time is 1 pm.  The campground is typically open May to mid-October, weather permitting, and when the East Portal road is open. Water is typically available mid-May to mid-September (after the last frost of spring and the first frost of fall).

name: Echo Bay Campground
description: Our Echo Bay Park is a fishermans and boaters paradise. Located on the north end of Lake Mead, this secluded park offers a variety of outdoor activities. Close to the must-see wonder of the Valley of Fire State Park and the ruins of the historic town of St. Thomas, visitors have an array of hiking and sightseeing opportunities. The large RV sites provide room for your boat, and the free on-site launch ramp are ideal for boaters.
passportStampLocationDescription: Please visit the visitor center for a passport stamp.

passportStampImages.altText: campsite
passportStampImages.title: Echo Bay

reservationInfo: This campground is managed by the National Park Service and is available on a first-come, first-served basis. For more information, please call 702-293-8990. Get a 50% discount with a Senior/Access Pass.

fees.description: Campground fees are $20 per site ($10 with the Interagency Senior and Access passes) and are payable immediately upon occupying a campsite. Fees are posted at the entrance to the campground. Sites managed by the National Park Service are available on a first-come, first-served basis. There are no reservations. Check-out time is noon.
fees.title: Campsite Fees

directionsOverview: Located on the northwestern part of Lake Mead. Access from the north from Overton, or from the south from the Las Vegas Valley. The Echo Bay turnoff is 10 miles south of the Northshore entrance station and 40 miles south of the Lake Mead Parkway entrance. Campground is about 5 miles from the turnoff to Echo Bay.

operatingHours.description: Standard hours. Quiet hours are 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m.
operatingHours.name: Echo Bay Campground

images.title: Echo Bay Campgrounds
images.altText: Campsite with desert trees and a picnic table.
images.caption: Echo Bay Campground

weatherOverview: Spring (April, May and June): Daytime highs 80 F to 98 F. Nighttime lows 50 F to 66 F Summer* (July, August and September): Daytime highs 89 F to 103 F (It can get up to 117 F.) Fall (October, November and December): Daytime highs 59 F to 83 F. Nighttime lows 32 F to 50 F. Winter (January, February and March) Daytime highs 57 F to 69 F. Nighttime lows 30 F to 40 F. *Summer can be a dangerous time due to excessive heat. Some trails are closed for public safety.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Campsites are flat but wheelchair access may be difficult at some sites.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are permitted in grills, fire rings, portable stoves, portable barbeques and portable fireplaces in all campgrounds and picnic areas. Please check the park website for seasonal fire restrictions.
accessibility.rvInfo: Campground roads are paved, some with a slight grade. Pads are paved, surrounded by natural desert landscape.
accessibility.adaInfo: Paved roadways and surfaces, restrooms, accessible picnic tables. Accessible sites: 8, 9 & 32

name: Echo Park Campground
description: Situated along the Green River at the base of towering cliffs, the Echo Park Campground provides a unique camping experience in Dinosaur National Monument. Steamboat Rock dominates the view. Fremont petroglyphs are located on the canyon walls. Bighorn sheep and mule deer frequently roam through the campground. Unimproved hiking trails lead to the confluence of the Green and Yampa Rivers or to views of the Mitten Park Fault. The campground is located 38 miles (61 km) north of the Canyon Visitor Center.
reservationInfo: Reservations are only available for the Group Campsite at the Echo Park Campground. All other sites are first-come, first-served. Reservations for the Group Campsite can be made below, or by calling Recreation.gov at 1-877-444-6777. Group sites can be reserved no more than 12 months in advance. The latest you can make a reservation is 24-hours in advance.
regulationsOverview: RVs & trailers prohibited. Truck-top campers & vans allowed. Each site is limited to 8 people and 2 vehicles. Group site allows up to 25 people. All vehicles must stay on gravel road or designated parking area. Dont block roads. Build campfires only in fire grates provided. Never leave fires unattended. Ensure fire is completely out and cold before leaving. Collecting wood from the ground or breaking it off trees/plants is prohibited. Use local firewood. Only burn wood, nothing else. Pets must be kept on a leash (6 feet maximum). Pets are allowed at campsites and within 100 feet of roads and parking lots. Dont leave pets unattended or tied to an object. Pets arent allowed on nearby hiking trails, on the river, or in the backcountry. Fireworks of any kind are prohibited. Dont feed or approach wildlife. Carry water to campsite for washing. Strain wastewater. Pack out all trash, solid food waste, and strained particles. Empty wastewater in vault toilet. Stays are limited to 14 consecutive days.

emailAddresses.description: Main Monument Email

fees.description: Summer fee when water is available.
fees.title: Summer Camping Fee

fees.description: Camping Fee when water is not available
fees.title: Winter Camping Fee

fees.description: One reservable group site is located at Echo Park Campground. Reservations can be made at Recreation.gov.
fees.title: Group Site

directionsOverview: Due to the rugged nature of the Echo Park Road, high-clearance vehicles with at least all-wheel-drive (AWD) are strongly recommended. RVs and trailers are not advised. The road is impassable for all vehicles when wet. From the Canyon Visitor Center in Dinosaur, Colorado, drive north on the Harpers Corner Road for 31 miles (39 km). Turn right onto the unpaved Echo Park Road. Take the Echo Park Road for 8 miles (13 km). At the fork, turn left and drive for 5 miles (8 km) to arrive at the Echo Park Campground.

operatingHours.description: Echo Park Campground is open year-round, but access is dependent on weather. The entire 13 mile (21 km) Echo Park Road is unpaved and impassable when wet. Winter access is often impossible due to snow on the Yampa Bench Road and the winter closure of the Harpers Corner Road.
operatingHours.name: Echo Park Campground

weatherOverview: Dinosaur's climate is semiarid with temperatures averaging between 0F to 30F (-18C to -1C) in January and 50F to 100F (10C to 38C) in July. Elevations within the park vary between 4,700 and 9,000 feet (1,433 and 2,743 m). Winter snow makes roads at higher elevations impassable while only light to moderate snow is found at lower elevations. Summer thunderstorms often cause heavy downpours and localized flooding, but may fail to dampen parched soils less than a mile away.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Wheelchair access is limited at the campground. Roads and parking areas are gravel. While the area is flat, wheelchair users may need assistance. The vault toilet is accessible to wheelchair users.
accessibility.cellPhoneInfo: Cell service is not available at the Echo Park Campground.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Campfires must be built inside the fire grates provided. Seasonal fire restrictions could be in effect. Check the information kiosk at the campground or ask a ranger about potential fire restrictions. To prevent the spread of invasive species, use local firewood. Collecting wood from the ground or breaking it off trees/plants is prohibited. Dont burn trash, metal, plastic, or other materials other than wood. Never leave fires unattended. Ensure fire is completely out and cold to the touch before leaving.
accessibility.rvInfo: RVs and trailers are not allowed. Tents, vans, and trucks with camper tops are permitted. There are no hookups, dump stations, or facilities for filling an RV water tank anywhere in Dinosaur National Monument.
accessibility.additionalInfo: There are no showers, hookups, dump stations, or facilities for filling an RV water tank anywhere in Dinosaur National Monument.
accessibility.adaInfo: Echo Park Campground has one designated accessible site.

name: El Morro Campground
description: El Morro National Monument operates a nine-site campground year-round. First come-first served. Each site has a graveled tent pad, picnic table and ground grill for fires. During the warmer months, water is available at spigots that are centrally located along the campground loop road. Once the overnight low's begin to reach freezing temperatures, water is turned off for the season. There are no hookups for RVs. The length limit on all motor homes is 27 feet overall. One site, #5, is handicapped accessible.
reservationInfo: No reservations; first come, first served.
regulationsOverview: Please follow all posted regulations. - Campsites are limited to no more than eight people, two tents, and two vehicles per site. Tents are restricted to the confines of each campsite. - Campfires: Fires are permitted in provided grills only. Please comply with any seasonal fire restrictions. Collection of firewood within the monument is prohibited, so bring firewood with you if you intend to have a campfire. Ensure that fires are extinguished completely after use. - The campground has a limit of 14 days per calendar year. - Quiet hours: From 10 p.m. to 6 a.m., including generators, radios, etc. - Pets must never be left unattended. Pets must always be kept on a leash no longer than 6 feet. Pet owners are responsible for cleanup and cleanup supplies. - The length limit on all RVs is 27 feet overall. This is measured from the front of the truck to the end of the trailer.

fees.description: There are no fees for the campground
fees.title: El Morro Campground

directionsOverview: From Albuquerque, NM, or from the east: take Interstate 40 west to Grants. At exit 81, go south on Highway 53 for 42 miles to El Morro National Monument. From Flagstaff, AZ, or from the west: take Interstate 40 east to Gallup. At exit 20, go south on Highway 602 for about 31 miles. Turn east (left) onto Highway 53. El Morro is 25 more miles. When you turn onto the El Morro park road, take a left at the sign towards the campground. The campground is 300 yards ahead.

operatingHours.description: Open all year
operatingHours.name: El Morro Campground

images.title: El Morro Campground
images.altText: El Morro Campsite
images.caption: El Morro Campground offers peace and quiet in a tranquil setting.

weatherOverview: At an elevation of 7,219 feet (2200 meters) winters can be cold and snowy. Summers are warm with afternoon thunder showers from mid-July through mid-September. Trails can close unexpectedly due to severe weather. Average snowfall: 40 inches per year. Average precipitation (snowmelt and rain): 16 inches per year. Warmest month: July, with average highs of 84 degrees and lows of 52 degrees. Coldest months: December and January, with average lows of 14-15 degrees, and average highs of 44-45 degrees.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: One site, #5, is handicapped accessible
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are permitted in provided grills only. Please comply with any seasonal fire restrictions. Collection of firewood within the monument is prohibited, so bring firewood with you if you intend to have a campfire
accessibility.rvInfo: RV's under 27 feet are allowed
accessibility.adaInfo: One site, #5, is handicapped accessible

name: Elk Creek Campground
description: Elk Creek Campground is located 16 miles west of Gunnison on U.S. Highway 50 on the shore of Blue Mesa Reservoir. We recommend making reservations prior to coming to Curecanti because cell service and first-come, first-served sites may be unavailable. Reservations may be made on recreation.gov from mid-May to mid-September. All types of camping from tents to large RVs can be accommodated. Very few sites have trees. This is the only campground with electricity (Loop D only) at Curecanti. Elevation: 7540 feet
reservationInfo: Loops A, B and D can be reserved for dates between May 26, 2021 and September 8, 2021. Dates are released on a 6-month rolling basis. Reservations need to be made at least one day in advance. We recommend making reservations prior to coming to Curecanti because cell service and first-come, first-served sites may be unavailable.

fees.description: $16.00 per night, plus $3.00 if reserved ($8.00 per night with Interagency Senior/Access Pass, plus $3.00 per night if reserved)

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Restrooms are accessible.

name: Elk Mountain Campground
description: This 62-site campground is open year round. Sites can be reserved at www.recreation.gov late May through September, and are first-come, first-served at all other times. Two sites are handicap-accessible. Flush toilets and drinking water are available late May through September. Fees are half-price when water is not available. Payment is by credit or debit card only. Two group campsites are also available through www.recreation.gov. Ranger programs are offered nightly in the amphitheater during the summer.
reservationInfo: All campsites can be reserved through www.recreation.gov late May through September. Sites are first-come, first-served at all other times. Payment is by credit or debit card only.
regulationsOverview: Overnight parking or camping is only allowed in designated campsites. Each campsite accommodates up to 8 people and one vehicle. Quiet hours are 10 pm through 6 am. Generators may run between 8 am and 8 pm. No unattended fires. There are trailer dump stations in Hot Springs and Custer. Do not dump waste water on the ground. There is a delicate cave system beneath the surface in this park; our actions can have a negative impact on it! Pets are welcome, but must be leashed at all times. Pets are only allowed on the Prairie Vista trail and the Elk Mountain Campground trail. Read more at https://www.nps.gov/wica/planyourvisit/pets.htm

fees.description: RV or tent rate when water and flush toilets are available. Senior (Golden Age)/Access pass holders pay half price. Interagency Annual Park Passes are not applicable for these fees.
fees.title: Campsite Fee

fees.description: RV or tent rate when water is not available. Senior (Golden Age)/Access pass holders pay half price. Interagency Annual Park Passes are not applicable for these fees.
fees.title: Campsite Fee - Off-season

directionsOverview: The Elk Mountain Campground is located about 11 miles north of Hot Springs, or 22 miles south of Custer, off U.S. Hwy 385, about 1/2 mile west of the highway. Follow the link below for detailed directions to the visitor center; the campground entrance is approximately 1/4 mile north of the visitor center.

operatingHours.description: The campground is open year-round with drinking water and flush toilets available late spring into early fall.  Fees are half-price when water is not available. Sites are first-come first-served and the campground rarely fills to capacity.
operatingHours.name: Elk Mountain Campground

images.caption: The Elk Mountain Campground is a first-come, first-served site. Campers can register the campsite of their choice the day of their stay, and drop their cash payment in the drop box.

images.title: Elk Mountain Campground Nature Trail
images.altText: The Elk Mountain Campground Nature Trail sign stands in front of the trail.
images.caption: The Elk Mountain Campground is a moderately strenuous, half mile hike through the campground. Leashed pets are welcome on this trail.

images.title: Elk Mountain Water Spigot
images.altText: A water spigot at the side of the road.
images.caption: There is potable water access seasonally in the campground.

weatherOverview: Spring: Highs range from 50-70F with highly variable weather. Spring is the park's wettest season. Summer: Hot and generally dry with daytime temperatures regularly exceeding 80F (27C). Strong thunderstorms are common and can produce large hail and lightning. Fall: Generally dry with warm days and cool nights. Highs 50-60F. Lows below freezing are common. Winter: Highs are in the high 30s with lows around 10F. Snowfall averages 30 inches annually, periodically closing park roads.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: There are two wheelchair accessible campsites at sites B2 and D3. There are wheelchair accessible vault toilets in B loop and seasonal accessible flush toilets in D loop. Campground amphitheater is wheelchair accessible.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are allowed in designated fire rings only and must not be left unattended. Extinguish all fires completely before leaving your campsite. Wood collection is not allowed, but firewood is available near the registration board.
accessibility.rvInfo: RV and trailers are allowed in the campground, however, drivers should be mindful of site selection. While there are sites which will accommodate a large RV or trailer, not all sites can do so.
accessibility.adaInfo: Campground amphitheater is wheelchair accessible with parking nearby.

name: Elk Prairie Campgound
description: Located in the heart of Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park.
reservationInfo: Year-round reservations available from Reserve California ph 1800 444-7275
regulationsOverview: The designated "Hike and Bike" camping sites are only for those visitors that hike in, or bicycle in. Visitors arriving by any vehicle may not use the "Hike and Bike" sites.

emailAddresses.description: Campground reservations and questions for "Reserve California" are handled from their website and phone-line.

fees.description: Per site.

directionsOverview: We are a six to seven hour drive north of San Francisco. This campground is located on the southern end of the Newton B. Drury Scenic Parkway. The closest exit off HWY 101 is exit #753.

operatingHours.description: Reservations are essential from May to October.

accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are only allowed in the provided fire rings, or in a portable camp stove.
accessibility.rvInfo: The limit is a 27-foot RV or a 24-foot trailer.
accessibility.adaInfo: Four cabins are ADA accessible.

name: Elkmont Campground
description: Elkmont Campground - elevation 2,150 feet (655m) - is the closest frontcountry camping area to Sugarlands Visitor Center in the North District of the park. The climate is characterized by mild winters and hot, humid summers. Mountain ranges and a pristine river are the backdrop for your Elkmont adventure. Elkmont Campground offers camping for both tents and RVs, with 220 sites total.
audioDescription: Elkmont Campground is a heavily forested area with a variety of tree species, both evergreen and deciduous. Depending on the time of year, you may find yourself surrounded by complete greenery or various stages of fall colors. Many sites sit along the river and others fall along the forest edge.
reservationInfo: Reservations are recommended to ensure availability but credit card payments may be processed on site. Sites may be reserved up to six months in advance.
regulationsOverview: All food and equipment used to prepare and store food must be kept sealed in a vehicle or in a camping unit constructed of solid, non-pliable material or as otherwise directed at all times when not in use. Campfires are permitted only in fire grates. You may collect wood in the park only if it is on the ground and dead. Beginning March 1, 2015 only heat-treated firewood that is bundled and certified by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) or a state agency may be brought into the park. Quiet hours are in effect from 10 pm to 6 am. Generator use is prohibited from 8 pm to 8 am. Your stay is limited to 14 consecutive days at a time. You may have up to six people per campsite. No more than two motor vehicles or one vehicle with trailer are allowed per campsite. Please keep wheels, including trailer wheels and guest cars, on the pavement. Park only in designated spaces. All tents must be pitched on the pad, where provided.

fees.description:
Reservations are recommended from May 15th - October 31st.
Maximum occupancy of each site is 6 people.  
No hook-ups, rest rooms with running water are available.
fees.title: Campsite

fees.description: Fee charged for riverside sites during reservation season May 15th - October 31st.

operatingHours.description: The campground typically closes seasonally in November and reopens in May the following year.

weatherOverview: This campground is in the mountains and weather can rapidly change from warm and sunny to cold and rainy. Be prepared with layers and rain gear in all seasons.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Amphitheatre is wheelchair accessible. Parking area, picnic table and fire ring at campsites are on paved surfaces.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Only heat-treated firewood which is in its original packaging and bears a certification from the USDA or a state agency may be brought into the park. You may also collect wood which is dead and down in the park to burn at your campsite. Fires are permitted only in established fire rings at campsite.
accessibility.rvInfo: All wheels of vehicles must fit on the paved surface in the parking area of each site. Generator hours 8AM - 8PM. No dump station on site, the closest is 6 miles away at Sugarlands Visitor Center.
accessibility.adaInfo: Elkmont has 10 accessible sites, campground roads are paved.

name: Elkmont Group Campground
description: These sites offers an ideal setting for group camping excursions and outdoor enthusiasts of all kinds.
reservationInfo: Available April 29th through October 31st.

accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Only heat-treated firewood which is in its original packaging and bears a certification from the USDA or a state agency may be brought into the park. You may also collect wood which is dead and down in the park to burn at your campsite. Fires are permitted only in established fire rings at campsite.

name: Elliott Key Campground
description: Elliott Key campground is located on an island. The only access is by boat. Elliott Key features waterside and partially forested camping areas, picnic tables, and grills. Restrooms with sinks and cold water showers are available. A mile-long loop hiking trail starts near the campground. Another walking trail, the infamous "Spite Highway" runs approximately six miles down the center of the island. At low tide, the depth of the entrance to the marina is approximately 2 1/2 feet.
audioDescription: The campground is on the bay side of the island, with sites in the grassy area by the water and under the forested canopy. Restrooms are located adjacent to the grassy camping area. A mile-long loop hiking trail starts near the campground. Another walking trail, the infamous "Spite Highway" runs approximately six miles down the center of the island from north to south.

fees.description: $35 per night including boat docking, $25 per night for tenting only. Download the free Recreation.gov app to pay your fees upon arrival using your mobile phone and Scan & Pay. Any vessel in the harbor after 5 pm is considered an overnight stay. Tenting fees are for a maximum of six people and two tents. Seniors with a valid America the Beautiful  The National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Senior Pass receive a 50% discount on fees.
fees.title: Camping Fees

operatingHours.description: Campgrounds Open 24 hours a Day
operatingHours.name: Elliott Key Campground

operatingHours.description: Campgrounds Open 24 hours a Day
operatingHours.name: Elliott Key Campground

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: The island is uneven and unpaved and not suitable for most mobility devices.
accessibility.rvInfo: Not allowed.
accessibility.adaInfo: The only access to the campground is by boat. There are no ADA campsites.

name: Emigrant Campground
description: First come / first served tent only campground with no additional fee. Located next to CA 190 at 2100' feet in elevation. Emigrant campground overlooks the Cottonwood Mountains which is a part of the Panamint Range. This is a small campground with 10 sites southwest of Stovepipe Wells Ranger Station. A building with flush toilets is 270 feet down a dirt trail just outside of the campground.
audioDescription: Campground is a flat, square-shaped, open, rocky, gravel space. 6 to 12 inch rocks are laid out in a line to mark the outside perimeter of the square campground. Lines of loose rocks extend into the open area to mark the boundaries of each of 10 tent spaces. Each space is approximately 30 feet wide by 40 feet deep. A metal picnic table is just inside the outer boundary of each space. The restroom is just outside the campground. A narrow, uneven gravel and rock social trail extends from the north-east corner of the campground 270 feet to a stone building. This building is the Emigrant wash room which sits along an asphalt road to the parking area beyond. Doorways to the bathrooms are behind privacy walls which open toward the parking area, women on the right side and men on the left side of the building. Gender signs are high above the privacy wall entrances. View to the far south is rounded hills with sharply eroded canyons. View to the east is the open end of a valley which opens to the pale brown floor of the rest of Death Valley. Low shrubs and rocky desert terrain surrounds the campground.
reservationInfo: All sites are first come/ first served, however NPS may hold sites at any time due to administrative needs.
regulationsOverview: Tents only. Limits: 30 days. No holding or reserving sites. 1 recreational vehicle w/ tow, 2 cars, or 4 motorcylces. 8 people per site. Checkout is 12 PM Noon. Fires: Fires including charcoal grills are prohibited. Gas burning stoves are permitted. Pets: Must be confined or or on a leash no longer than 6 feet. Do not leave unattended. Allowed in developed areas or along roads only. Owners are responsible for cleanup. Wildlife: All unattended food, garbage or cooking equipment must be sealed in a vehicle or an animal-resistant container. Please dispose of all trash in receptacles provided. Do not feed or disturb wildlife. Coyotes and ravens are scavengers.

fees.description: Free.  There is no cost to camp here.  Please pay your park entry fee.
fees.title: Emigrant Campground Camping Fee

directionsOverview: 40 min from the Furnace Creek Visitor Center. From the visitor center, turn left on CA190 and drive west past Stovepipe Wells. Emigrant Campground is 10 miles southwest of Stovepipe Wells.

operatingHours.description: Open year round first come/first served.
operatingHours.name: Emigrant Campground

accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Gas burning stoves are permitted. Fires and charcoal grills are prohibited.

accessRoads: Unpaved Roads - All vehicles OK in good weather

name: Erbie Campground
description: Erbie Campground is a first come, first serve campground. Erbie has 14 drive in camp sites, 2 walk in tent only sites, and 5 group sites. There are no electrical amenities, flush restrooms, or water available.
audioDescription: Erbie campground is about 5 1/2 miles on a gravel road off of Highway 7 about 3 miles north of Jasper, AR. The road winds through woodlands including at least one hairpin curve. The road straightens out into the valley. The turn into the campground is on the right. Straight ahead takes you to the historic Parker Hickman farmstead. When you turn into the campground the road to the right goes to parking and river access point. To the left is the campground with large groups sites in the field on the right. Past the group sites are individual campsites amongst the trees.
reservationInfo: Group sites 2, 3, and 4 are reservable by calling the Tyler Bend Visitor Center at 870-439-2502. Group sites 1 and 5 are first come, first serve. Each group site is permitted to have up to 25 people per site, tent camping only. All drive in and walk in sites are first come, first serve. Drive in and tent only sites are limited to 6 people per site.
regulationsOverview: Quiet hours are between 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. Generators may be used between 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. Maximum length of stay in campground is 14 consecutive days. Use the trash receptacles for all other refuse. These measures will help prevent nuisance wildlife and keep the campground clean. Washing anything in the river is prohibited. You may use dead and down wood for firewood. All fires should be completely out when campsite is unattended. At all times, pets must be confined or on a leash not more than 6 feet in length. Pets should not be left unattended. Clean up after pets. IN CASE OF EMERGENCY: contact Park Dispatch at 888-692-1162. Report all accidents and lost and found property to a ranger.

fees.description: There is no fee to camp at Erbie. Six people are permitted per site. The vault restrooms are open year round. The five group sites (10 - 25 people allowed per group site) are also free to camp at. If you would like to make a reservation for a group site please call the Tyler Bend Visitor Center at 870-439-2502.
fees.title: Erbie Camping Fee

directionsOverview: The Erbie Campground is located north of Jasper, Arkansas. Take Highway 7 north of Jasper for approximately 3 miles. Turn left onto County Road 79 and the Erbie Campground will be approximately 6 miles down a gravel road with one hairpin curve.

operatingHours.description: Erbie is a first come, first serve campground. No fee is charged to camp here.
operatingHours.name: Erbie Campground

weatherOverview: Summer in the Ozarks can be very hot and humid. Please check the weather forecast prior to your arrival and plan accordingly. The weather the rest of the year has the potential to be wet and cool or dry and warm. Please pay special attention to river levels and the rain forecast when planning a trip on the river. River levels can rise dramatically in a short period of time so please be aware of conditions.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: The terrain is grassy and uneven.
accessibility.cellPhoneInfo: Cell phone service is not reliable unless you drive several miles towards Jasper on Highway 7.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Please keep fires in the designated fire rings. Cook stoves are allowed.
accessibility.rvInfo: RVs and trailers are allowed in the campground. No hookups available.
accessibility.additionalInfo: An emergency phone is available at the vault restroom near the launch area. This phone can also be used to call the local canoe concessionaires.
accessibility.adaInfo: Erbie Campground does not have any ADA compliant campsites. The restroom facilities are ADA compliant.
accessRoads: Unpaved Roads - All vehicles OK in good weather

name: Esker Campsite
description: Hike or bike approximately 2.2 miles from the Wassataquoik Gate to the Esker Campsite, located on the bank of Wassataquoik Stream.
reservationInfo: First-come, first-serve.

fees.description: No fee required
fees.title: Walk-in, tent-only site

directionsOverview: From the intersection of Maine State Route 11 and Swift Brook Road in Stacyville, it is approximately 12 miles to the Katahdin Loop Road. From the start of the Loop Road, it is approximately 5.5 miles to the parking area at the Wassataquoik Gate. From the parking area, hike or bike approximately 2.2 miles to the Esker Campsite.

operatingHours.description: The Esker Campsite is open year-round. Access by vehicle via Swift Brook Road and the Katahdin Loop Road is typically available from late May-early November. At other times of year, the Esker campsite would only be accessible by foot or boat.
operatingHours.name: Esker Campsite

images.altText: A picnic table, fire ring, and clearing for a tent on the bank of Wassataquoik Stream.
images.caption: Esker Campsite is located on the west bank of Wassataquoik Stream.

weatherOverview: https://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-68.6784771573313&lat=45.90685318981835#.YJVGiLVKhPY

accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Camp stoves allowed. Campfires can only be kindled with a valid Maine Forest Service campfire permit and only in designated locations such as established campsites and lean-tos. A free permit is easily acquired prior to a visit by contacting the Maine Forest Service at the address or phone listed below: Maine Forest Service-Northern Region Headquarters 45 Radar Rd Ashland, ME 04732 207-435-7963 Untreated firewood from out of state is banned. Firewood brought in from other areas may contain non-native insect species that pose a serious threat to park resources. Quarantines have been issued for some areas. Please leave your firewood at home. Firewood is available locally in surrounding communities.

name: Eureka Dunes Campground (Primitive)
description: Remote campground at the base of Eureka Dunes (the tallest sand dunes in California and home to several endemic plant species). This campground is located at 2,880ft and is only accessible to high-clearance vehicles. Please drive only on existing roads and tread lightly on the dunes to protect this fragile and unique environment.
reservationInfo: All sites first-come-first-served.
regulationsOverview: Campsites are limited to no more than eight people and two vehicles.  Charcoal producing fires may only be made in NPS metal fire pits.  All stoves and grills must be gas burning.  Pets: Pets must never be left unattended. There is a maximum limit of 4 pets per campsite and pets must be kept on a leash no longer than 6 feet at all times. Pet owners are responsible for cleanup and cleanup supplies.  Wildlife: Coyotes and ravens are scavengers - keep your campsite clean! Do NOT feed or disturb wildlife.  Driving on the dunes or off established roads is prohibited.

fees.description: Park entry fee/pass required. No additional camping fee.
fees.title: Backcountry Campground

directionsOverview: Off of CA190 at the junction for Scottys Castle road, travel north thirty-eight (38) miles and take a right on unpaved Big Pine road. Travel thirty-four (34) miles on Big Pine road and take a left on South Eureka Valley Road. Travel ten (10) miles south to Eureka Dune dry camp.

operatingHours.description: Open year-round, first-come-first-served. Camping here during summer months is not recommended due to high temperatures.
operatingHours.name: Eureka Dunes Dry Camp

accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires allowed in designated rings only. Do not build additional rings. Propane cook stoves with on/off valve are permitted.
accessibility.rvInfo: RVs and Trailers not recommended due to rough roads. High Clearance/4WD recommended.
accessibility.adaInfo: Primitive campground. No ADA sites available.

name: Evans Campground
description: Evans Campground runs lengthwise along the lakeshore. One end is capped with the group sites and the boat launch. The other end is a Day Use Area with a covered picnic area and swim beach. The campground is busy in the summer and tends to fill on the weekends.

passportStampImages.altText: A virtual passport stamp with an overview of the lake, with hills and trees surrounding it.
passportStampImages.title: Lake Roosevelt Virtual Visit 2022

reservationInfo: All sites are reservation only.
regulationsOverview: Maximum Stay: Camping is limited to 14 consecutive nights per campground within a 30 day period and not more than 60 total nights per calendar year anywhere within LRNRA. These limits apply to all camping activities within LRNRA. Check-Out Time: Noon Quiet Hours: From 10 pm to 6 am. This includes generators. Nighttime Closures: Campgrounds are closed to non-registered campers from 10 pm to 6am. Site Occupation: All sites MUST be occupied each night. You may not pay for these sites and leave your belongings in them without nightly occupancy Property left unattended for 24 hours will be considered abandoned. No more than two vehicles and ten people at each campsite. Leave No Trace: The wheels of all vehicles and trailers must be within the designated parking space and not on the roadway or vegetation. Do not attach wires, ropes, or nails to trees or shrubs. Digging, leveling, or other alterations of the ground is not permitted.

fees.description: The fee for an individual campsite per night from May 1 through September 30. Group size limit is 10 people and 2 vehicles.
fees.title: Title: Standard Camping Fee, May 1  September 30

fees.description: Discounted camping rate for valid America the Beautiful Senior or Access passes. The fee for an individual campsite per night from May 1 through September 30. Group size limit is 10 people and 2 vehicles.
fees.title: Senior / Access Rate, May 1  September 30

fees.description: The fee for an individual campsite per night from October 1 through April 30. Group size limit is 10 people and 2 vehicles.
fees.title: Standard Camping Fee, October 1  April 30

fees.description: Discounted camping rate for valid America the Beautiful Senior or Access passes. The fee for an individual campsite per night from October 1 through April 30. Group size limit is 10 people and 2 vehicles.
fees.title: Senior / Access Rate, October 1  April 30

directionsOverview: Evans is located off of WA 25. From Kettle Falls, drive north on US 395. Turn right onto WA 25 North. Follow WA 25 North for approximately 9 miles. Turn left at the Evans Campground sign.

operatingHours.description: Evans Campground is open year-round, but amenities like flush restrooms, water, and the dump station are not available in winter.  They become available again when weather and lake water level allow.
operatingHours.name: Evans Campground
