weatherOverview: At 4,400 feet in elevation, Hole-in-the-Wall is a respite from summer heat at lower elevations. In late summer, strong monsoonal storms can drop large amounts of rain and flood low-lying areas, making roads in and out of the campground hazardous. Fall brings cooler temperatures and marks the beginning of hunting season. Winter brings freezing temperatures and occasional snow.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Campground is unpaved, consisting of packed dirt and gravel. Wheelchair-accessible restrooms are located at the nearby Hole-in-the-Wall Visitor Center
accessibility.cellPhoneInfo: Cell phone service is unreliable in this area.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are limited to provided fire rings. Wood cannot be collected in the park. Visitors must bring in their own wood.
accessibility.rvInfo: RVs and trailers are welcome at Hole-in-the-Wall Campground. Most sites can accommodate a maximum length of 33 feet, although 2 pull-though sites can accommodate longer lengths. All sites are first-come, first-served.
accessibility.adaInfo: No sites are specially designed for ADA access.

name: Homestake Campground (Primitive)
description: Extremely remote campsite at 3,785ft of elevation, accessible only by high-clearance vehicles with all-terrain tires. Access from Saline Valley Road requires navigating Lippincott Pass and should only be attempted by experienced 4-wheel drivers. There are no approved toilet facilities at this location and no water available. Pack in all that you need, pack out all that you bring.
reservationInfo: No Reservations
regulationsOverview: Charcoal producing fires may only be made in NPS metal fire pits.  All stoves and grills must be gas burning.  Pets must never be left unattended. There is a maximum limit of 4 pets per campsite and pets must be kept on a leash no longer than 6 feet at all times. Pet owners are responsible for cleanup and cleanup supplies.  Coyotes and ravens are scavengers - keep your campsite clean! Do NOT feed or disturb wildlife.

fees.description: Free (Death Valley entrance fee or Annual/Lifetime Pass required)
fees.title: Camping Fee

directionsOverview: Off of CA190 at the junction for Scottys Castle road, travel north thirty-eight (38) miles toward Ubehebe Crater. Just before the parking area for the crater, turn right onto unpaved Racetrack Road. Travel 20 miles on this high clearance 4WD road and take a right at Teakettle Junction. Travel 9.5 miles and just past the Racetrack playa arrive at the campground.

operatingHours.description: Open year-round, first-come-first-served.
operatingHours.name: Homestake Dry Camp

accessibility.rvInfo: Not suitable for RVs and trailers. Access is high clearance /4 WD.
accessibility.adaInfo: Campground is not ADA accessible.

name: Horse Camp
description: Horse Camp is specifically for camping with horses. The open area allow ease of parking for horse trailers. Several trails are accessible from this campground. Both sites are in partial shade and feature bear-proof storage lockers, picnic tables, a lamp pole, fire pit with swing-arm BBQ grill, and a shared ADA accessible vault toilet. Each site has a maximum occupancy of 10 people and 3 vehicles. Potable water available from a spigot most the year. No corrals, tie posts/rails, or water troughs onsite.
audioDescription: Horse Camp is a primitive campground with two sites that can each accommodate up to 10 people. It is located about two miles down Paige Bar Road from Kennedy Memorial Drive. The last half mile of the road is gravel. A large parking area separates the two sites and can accommodate up to three vehicles per site, including large RVs and trailers. There is an ADA accessible vault toilet on the east end of the parking lot and a hand pump is available for water. Each site includes two picnic tables, a fire ring and swing-arm grill, a bear-resistant food storage locker, and a lantern pole. Three vehicles and three tents maximum. Sites are open and sunny with some light shade under pine and oak trees. Horses are allowed, although no corrals or hitching poles are provided. Several trails can be accessed directly from the campground or from Mule Town Road, which is a dirt road crossing Paige Bar Road a short distance past the campground. The Guardian Rock trail begins at the south side of the parking lot as a paved ADA accessible path to an overlook of Clear Creek one quarter mile from the trailhead. This trail continues as a dirt path and follows Clear Creek upstream for an additional three quarters of a mile to an alternate trailhead.
reservationInfo: Reservations are required for these campsites.
regulationsOverview: Reservations are required for these campsites. You may stay a total of 14 days from May 15 through September 15 or a total of 30 days for the entire calendar year. Maximum occupancy is 10 people, 3 vehicles, and 3 vehicles per site. Check-in time is 1:00 pm. and check-out time is 12 pm. (noon). Please be respectful of other visitors and the park environment by keeping noise levels down. Park law enforcement rangers regularly patrol campgrounds.

fees.description: This is the nightly cost for a tent-only site Maximum occupancy: 6 people and two vehicles. Pay for your site online at Recreation.gov or call toll free 1-877-444-6777. This is the only way to pay for or reserve a site at the campground. We no longer accept payment at the Whiskeytown visitor center.
fees.title: Horse Camp camping fee

operatingHours.description: Horse Camp campground is open year-round. Contact the Visitor Center at (530) 246-1225 for information on availability. Groups with horses may reserve this site by calling (530) 242-3412. Groups without horses may use this site on a first-come/first-served basis.

weatherOverview: Summers are hot and dry. Winters can be cold and wet.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: These sites feature uneven, unpaved terrain and steep drops in some areas. Vehicles can park at campsite. Vault toilets are ADA-accessible.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Campfires are allowed in designated fire rings unless fire restrictions are in effect. The use of gas lanterns & stoves are allowed unless current fire restrictions prohibit them. Do not leave campfires unattended. Always make sure that your fire is completely extinguished before you leave your campsite or before you go to sleep for the night.
accessibility.rvInfo: Any vehicles or combination of vehicles, including trailers, RVs, and RVs pulling other vehicles that do no exceed 25' in total length are allowed at Horse Camp.
accessibility.additionalInfo: No generators are allowed
accessibility.adaInfo: These sites feature uneven, unpaved terrain and steep drops in some areas. Vehicles can park at campsite. Vault toilets are ADA-accessible.
accessRoads: Unpaved Roads - All vehicles OK in good weather

name: Horse camping
description: Campground accessible for horses and riders to camp overnight
reservationInfo: National Park Service Reservation System Reservations are required from October 16 through April 14. Campsite reservations are available six months in advance. Be aware that nearly all reservations for weekends are filled the first day that they become available. Call the toll-free reservation line: 1-877-444-6777 (10:00 AM - 10:00 PM EST)
regulationsOverview: Each campsite will accommodate up to six people and six horses. Campsites include hitching posts, fire rings, picnic tables, restrooms and potable water. Do not leave your horse unattended. Wild horses are present in all areas of the park and may frighten your animals. Use processed feed to eliminate introducing weed seeds into the park. Never leave feed where wildlife can get it. Only tie horses to the hitching posts. Campers are allowed to bring portable corrals. Remove all manure piles within the campsite

fees.description:
Tents, trailers and recreational vehicles (no hookups). Sites have a picnic table and a fire ring. 
Sites are $50 per night.
fees.title: Camping fee

fees.description:
All vehicles are subject to an entrance fee. 
Entrance fee is valid for 1-7 days for reentry into the park.
Current Assateague Pass, IA-Annual Pass, IA-Senior Pass, IA-Access Pass. IA-4th Grade, IA-Military Pass, IA Golden Age Passport and IA-Golden Access Passport are valid for entry.
fees.title: Vehicle Entrance Fee

directionsOverview: Warning about GPS Systems! Vehicle Navigation Systems and GPS units may provide inaccurate information sending drivers to wrong destinations.

weatherOverview: Spring: Often windy and cool with lows in the 40's and highs in the 60's. Summer: Hot and humid with lows in the 60's and highs in the 80's. Fall: Warm with lows in the 50's and highs in the 70's. Winter: Damp cold and often windy. Lows in the 20's, highs in the 40's. http://www.nps.gov/asis/planyourvisit/weather.htm

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Wheelchair accessible trails - Maryland District Life of the Forest Trail- 1/2 mile loop Life of the Marsh Trail - 1/2 mile loop Bicycle Bridge - 1/2 mile
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Campers may not bring firewood from out of state. Firewood must be purchased locally.
accessibility.rvInfo: Rvs, Trailers and Tents allowed
accessibility.adaInfo: All visitor centers, most nature trails, bathhouses and wayside exhibits are accessible. America the Beautiful - Access Pass National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Pass This is a free, lifetime pass for U.S. citizens or permanent residents of the United States that have been medically determined to have a permanent disability. The pass provides access to, and use of, Federal recreation sites that charge an Entrance or Standard Amenity fee. It replaces the Golden Access Pass. Golden Access passes may be exchanged free of charge. Beach wheelchairs with balloon tires are available for use on the oceanside beaches in Maryland and Virginia. For more information please check at the Ranger Station in Maryland (410-641-3030). Service animals are allowed in National Parks. For a definition of a service animal please visit www.ada.gov/service_animals_2010.htm

name: Horsepen Branch Hiker-Biker Campsite
description: Mile 26.1 - Hiker-biker campgrounds are located along the towpath approximately every 5-7 miles. No fee or reservation required. Overnight stays are limited to one night. All sites include a chemical toilet, picnic table, grill, and drinking water. Please Note: Potable water may not be available at each campsite. Water is treated with iodine. Please plan to have water purification tablets with you. Water is turned off from November 15 to April 15 each year.
audioDescription: (102 words) The nearest parking to Horsepen Branch Hiker-Biker Campsite is the Sycamore Landing parking area. From the parking lot head toward a towpath access trail at the mid point of the southern edge of the lot. Once on the access trail it is 100 feet to the towpath. Turn left, East, onto the towpath, traveling for 1.1 miles to the campsite on your right. You will pass a water pump about 50 feet before the access trail for the campsite breaks off to the right. The campground is large, flat and lightly wooded. It sits between the towpath and the Potomac River.
reservationInfo: First come, first served

fees.description: First-come, first served.
fees.title: Walk-in, tent-only site

operatingHours.description: Campground is open year-round. Water is generally available from mid-April to mid-November.
operatingHours.name: Horsepen Branch Hiker-Biker Overnight (HBO) Campsite

weatherOverview: Campsites are near the Potomac River and are subject to flooding after heavy rains.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Gravel, non-level terrain
accessibility.cellPhoneInfo: Cell phone reception is spotty throughout the park and is dependent on the carrier.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are restricted to the grills and fire rings provided or to portable grills positioned off the ground. Coals must be extinguished and removed from the park. Firewood may be collected from dead material on the ground but for use in campgrounds only. Do not remove wood from the campground. Firewood cannot be brought into the park.
accessibility.rvInfo: N/A
accessibility.adaInfo: Not ADA accessible

name: Horseshoe Bend Campground
description: - Located near Lovell, WY - Open All Year - All sites include fire pit and picnic table. - 68 RV and tent sites - 28 sites have water and electrical hook-ups. The water is only available at these sites Memorial Day to Labor Day. The electricity remain on year round. - 3 pull through sites - Modern Restrooms, RV dump station and drinking water are available - Swim beach and picnic less than 1 mile hike from the campground - Horseshoe Bend Marina and boat docks less than 1 mile hike from the campground
reservationInfo: Most campsites are first come, first serve. There are 5 reservable sites. Reservations online only.
regulationsOverview: 1. Overnight stays/camping in park is only allowed in established sites 2. Check-out is 12:00 pm 3. Quiet hours from 10:00 pm to 6:00 am; idling of motor vehicles is prohibited during quiet hours 4. Generators permitted from 8 am to 8 pm 5. Campsite occupancy may not exceed 14 cumulative days within a 28-day period 6. Collection of firewood is prohibited within the park 7. No attaching or tying items to trees 8. Pets must be leashed at all times and may not be left unattended

fees.description:
The sites with electrical and water hook-ups are $30 (which includes sales tax) per night per site. Only one RV is allowed per site. No discounts apply. Add 4% for credit cards. Please make checks payable to: Hidden Treasure Charters.

Fee free during off season (October 30 through mid April 15). No utilities during this time either.
fees.title: Horseshoe Bend Campground fee for Utility sites

fees.description:
The Horseshoe Bend Campground fee for sites without hook-ups is $18 per site (includes sales tax), per night. Only one RV is allowed per site. NPS Senior Pass discounted price $9 per night. Add 4% for credit cards. Please make checks payable to: Hidden Treasure Charters.

Fee free during off season (October 30 through mid April 15).
fees.title: Horseshoe Bend Campground Fee for Non-Utility sites

directionsOverview: From the intersection of 14A E and 37, travel North on 37, 9.7 miles. Look for the sign for Horseshoe Bend and turn right. Continue for 1.4 miles to camp grounds located to the left of the road prior to the marina.

operatingHours.description: Open year round. Campground host on site Memorial Day - Labor Day.
operatingHours.name: Horseshoe Bend Campground

images.title: Horseshoe Bend Campground Map
images.altText: Simple map of a campground's site layout
images.caption: Horseshoe Bend is one of the most popular, and more accessible, campgrounds at the park.

images.title: Horseshoe Bend Campground

images.caption: Horseshoe Bend Campground

images.title: Horseshoe Bend Campground from loop B
images.altText: A paved road with gravel campsites disperse in a dessert plain with bright blue sky and a few clouds
images.caption: Horseshoe Bend Campground from loop B

weatherOverview: https://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.888&lon=-108.1887#.XO7-RIi6OUl

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: ADA is limited. Paths and camp sites are gravel and level. Bathrooms are wheelchair accessible but do not have automatic openers.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Check locally, dependent on conditions.
accessibility.rvInfo: There are utility and non-utility sites. Sites accommodate small RV's to larger sites that accommodate large RV plus vehicle and boat. There are two pull through sites.
accessibility.adaInfo: ADA is limited. Paths and camp sites are gravel and level. Bathrooms are wheelchair accessible but do not have automatic openers.

name: Horseshoe Bend Hiker-Biker Campsite
description: Mile 79.2 - Hiker-biker campgrounds are located along the towpath approximately every 5-7 miles. No fee or reservation required. Overnight stays are limited to one night. All sites include a chemical toilet, picnic table, grill, and drinking water. Please Note: Potable water may not be available at each campsite. Water is treated with iodine. Please plan to have water purification tablets with you. Water is turned off from mid-November to mid-April each year.
audioDescription: (83 words) The nearest parking lot to Horseshoe Bend Hiker-Biker Campsite is at Taylors Landing. The road to the parking lot crosses a bridge over the canal. The towpath is just after the bridge. Coming from the parking lot, you would turn right (or downriver) onto the towpath, following it for 1.7 miles. The trail to the campsite is near the water pump and descends slightly to the small, narrow, flat, grassy camping area between the Potomac River and the C&O towpath. End of description.
reservationInfo: First come, first served

fees.description: Sleeps 8 people, 2 tents
fees.title: Walk-in, tent-only site

operatingHours.description: Campground is open year-round. Water is generally available from mid-April to mid-November.
operatingHours.name: Horseshoe Bend Hiker-Biker Overnight (HBO) Campsite

images.title: Horseshoe Bend Hiker-Biker Campsite
images.altText: A campsite in the trees surrounded by a fence.
images.caption: Horseshoe Bend Hiker-Biker Campsite

weatherOverview: Campsites are located in close proximity to the Potomac River and are subject to flooding after heavy rains.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Unpaved, uneven surfaces
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are restricted to the grills and fire rings provided or to portable grills positioned off the ground. Firewood may be collected from dead material on the ground but for use in campgrounds only. Do not remove wood from the campground. Firewood cannot be brought into the park.
accessibility.rvInfo: N/A
accessibility.adaInfo: Not ADA accessible

name: Hosmer Grove Campground
description: Hosmer Grove lies in the cloud belt of Haleakal, just below the 7,000 foot level (2134m) in the Summit District. Be prepared for rain and cold weather. Nighttime temperatures can drop into the to near freezing (0C); daytime highs average 50-65F (10-18C). The campground has picnic tables, barbeque grills, drinking water, and pit toilets. Overnight stays are limited to three (3) nights total for all Park areas in a thirty day period.
reservationInfo: Reservations are required to camp at Hosmer Grove Campground.
regulationsOverview: Overnight stays are limited to three (3) nights total for all Park areas in a 30-day period.

fees.description: Fee to reserve 1 campsite for 1 night at Hosmer Grove.
fees.title: Reservation Fee - Per Night

fees.description: All park visitors are required to purchase a 3-day Entrance Pass at the Entrance Gate upon arrival to the park. The campsite reservation does not cover your Entrance Pass. An automated entrance pass machine is available after hours.
fees.title: Entrance Fee - Per Vehicle

directionsOverview: Seven hundred feet past the Summit District Entrance Station, turn left at the four-way intersection, following signs for Hosmer Grove Campground. Follow the road for .5 mile to reach the campground parking lot.

operatingHours.description: Hosmer Grove Campground is open year-round.
operatingHours.name: Hosmer Grove Campground

images.title: Hosmer Grove Campground Area
images.altText: A gray tent is pitched next to a grill and picnic table. Tall shrubs and grass line the area.
images.caption: Immerse yourself in the native shrubland of Haleakal.

weatherOverview: The weather in the Summit District can change quickly from warm and sunny to cold and rainy. Hosmer Grove Campground lies in the cloudbelt of Haleakal, and as such often sees misty, rainy, and wet conditions during winter months and in the afternoons. It is advised to have rain gear and a rain fly when undertaking outdoor activities.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: There there is one narrow, paved path that leads to the first site only. The campsites are on a sloping, grassy field.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are only permitted in designated barbeque grills. Gas stoves are permitted. There are no ground fires allowed.
accessibility.rvInfo: There are not spots available for RVs or trailers.
accessibility.adaInfo: Pit toilet restrooms by the campground parking lot are accessible. There are no designated accessible campsites. The campsites are spread across a sloping, grassy field directly across from the parking lot.

name: Houchin Ferry Campground
description: The Houchin Ferry Campground lies next to the Green River at the former location of the Houchin Ferry. This campground is operated year-round and is located 15 miles from the Visitor Center and two miles east of Brownsville, KY. For campers who like it simple, these 12 tent-only campsites afford a quiet visit with drive-up access.
reservationInfo: Campsites are through reservations only.
regulationsOverview: Camp only in designated sites.  Pay the camping fee at the entrance kiosk. No refunds.  Check-in time is 12 noon. Check-out time is 11 am.  Maximum of 8 persons per site. Maximum 14 day stay in calendar year.  Quiet hours: 10 pm - 6 am. Generators are permitted from 8 am to 8 pm as long as they are properly muffled and do not create unreasonable noise.  Mark your occupied campsite when you leave.  Articles left unattended on an unpaid campsite for 24 hours may be impounded.  Do not dig, trench, or level ground at your campsite.  Deposit refuse in dumpsters or carry it out with you when you leave.  Do not wash dishes or clothing at water hydrants.  Catch your drain water in buckets and empty into toilets in the restrooms.  Store your camp food inside a vehicle to prevent wildlife access. This is a listing only of general regulations. Please familiarize yourself with all of the camping regulations before camping at Houchin Ferry Campground.

emailAddresses.description: Mammoth Cave National Park visitor information email

fees.description: Each site has a fire ring and picnic table. Each site is accessible by vehicle. Maximum number of campers is 8, maximum stay is 14 days in a calendar year.
fees.title: Houchin Ferry Campground - Primitive Site - Regular

fees.description: Each site has a fire ring and picnic table. Each site is accessible by vehicle. Maximum number of campers is 8, maximum stay is 14 days in a calendar year.
fees.title: Houchin Ferry Campground - Primitive Site - Access Card

directionsOverview: Follow I-65 to Ky-70W to Brownsville, Kentucky. At the intersection of Houchins Ferry Road on your right, turn right onto Houchins Ferry Road. Houchins Ferry Road ends at Green River. Houchin Ferry Campground is at the end of the road.

operatingHours.description: Open Year-Round
operatingHours.name: Houchin Ferry Campground

images.title: Houchin Ferry Campground - Campsite
images.altText: Campsites with picnic tables nearby the river.
images.caption: At Houchin Ferry Campground, every site has a river view.

images.title: Houchin Ferry Campground - Simple Camping
images.altText: A Houchin Ferry campsite with tent, fire ring, picnic table and lantern hook overlooks Green River.
images.caption: Houchin Ferry Campground sites may be primitive sites - but they're welcoming.

images.title: Houchin Ferry Campground - Primitive Campsites
images.altText: An unoccupied campsite with concrete picnic table, fire ring and lantern hook.
images.caption: This campground's primitive sites feature a picnic table, fire ring, and lantern hook.

images.title: Houchin Ferry Campground - Picnic Shelter
images.altText: An open-air picnic shelter with multiple picnic tables and a brick fireplace.
images.caption: Houchin Ferry Campground also offers an open-air picnic shelter with a fireplace.

images.title: Houchin Ferry Campground - Toilet Facilities
images.altText: A wooden enclosure containing portable toilet facilities.
images.caption: Chemical toilets are provided at Houchin Ferry Campground.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: The sites in this campground are on unimproved ground, with gravel-paved approaches.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Keep fires within provided fire rings. Use only dead and down wood for fires. Observe posted fire condition warnings and regulations.
accessibility.rvInfo: RVs are not permitted at this campground.
accessibility.adaInfo: Houchin Ferry Campground's campsites are primitive. There are no ADA accessible campsites in this campground.
accessRoads: Unpaved Roads - All vehicles OK in good weather

name: Hovenweep Campground
description: A 31-site campground near the visitor center is open year-round, first-come, first-served. The campground is designed for tent camping, though a few sites will accommodate RVs up to 36 feet long. Groups are limited to eight people and two vehicles. Sites include tent pads, fire rings and picnic tables with shade structures; there are no hookups available. One campsite is wheelchair-accessible but is not designed for tent camping.
reservationInfo: We do not accept reservations. All campsites are first-come, first-served.
regulationsOverview: Camping is only permitted in the designated campground. Campsites may not be held for parties arriving later. Each campsite is limited to 8 persons, 2 tents, and 2 vehicles (a trailer counts as one vehicle). Campsites may not be left unattended for more than 24 hours. All motor vehicles must be parked on designated vehicle pads and must not extend into the roadway. Vehicle barriers may not be moved to enlarge the available parking space. Campground Generator Hours are from 8am-10am and from 4pm-8pm. Campground Quiet Hours are from 10pm-8am. Noise levels are to remain at a conversational level. Visitors are prohibited from soliciting other campers to share their campsites. Checkout time is 10am daily. Camping fees are to be paid and deposited within 30 minutes of occupying a campsite. Camping permit stubs must be displayed on the campsite marker immediately after payment is deposited. Length of stay is limited to 7 consecutive days from April 15 - October 15, and 14 consecutive days otherwise.

fees.description: The nightly camping fee at Hovenweep is $15, all year. Group size limit is eight people and two vehicles.
fees.title: Standard Camping Fee

fees.description: Discounted camping rate for valid Senior or Access passes. The nightly camping fee with valid passes is $7.50 per site, all year. Group size limit is eight people and two vehicles.
fees.title: Senior/ Access Rate

directionsOverview: Do not use GPS to find your way. There are numerous paved and dirt roads intersecting each other in this remote corner of Utah. The Hovenweep Visitor Center is located 40-45 miles from Cortez, Colorado, and Blanding and Bluff, Utah. Follow driving directions on our webpage.

operatingHours.description: Hovenweep Campground is open year-round.
operatingHours.name: Hovenweep Campground

addresses.line1: Along the border between southeast Utah and southwest Colorado
addresses.line2: Just north and west of Cortez, CO

images.title: Campsite
images.altText: a gravel area with a picnic table under a shade structure
images.caption: Campsites have picnic tables with shade structures

images.title: Campground
images.altText: RVs and trucks parked at campsites
images.caption: Hovenweep Campground has 31 sites

weatherOverview: Hovenweep is part of the Colorado Plateau, a "high desert" region that experiences wide temperature fluctuations, sometimes over 40 degrees in a single day. The temperate (and most popular) seasons are spring (April-May) and fall (mid-September-October), when daytime highs average 60 to 80 F and lows average 30 to 50 F. Summer temperatures often exceed 100 F, making strenuous exercise difficult. Winters are cold, with highs averaging 30 to 50 F, and lows averaging 0 to 20 F.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: The road through the campground is paved with a gentle slope. The trail to the amphitheater has rocky stairs and is not accessible to a wheelchair. The restrooms are wheelchair accessible.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Wood fires in grates only. Wood gathering is prohibited. Do not leave garbage in fire grates. Charcoal cooking fires are allowed in fire pans and grills. Place ashes in fire grates. Properly extinguish all fires.
accessibility.rvInfo: The 31-site campground is designed for tent camping, though a few sites will accommodate RVs up to 36 feet long.
accessibility.adaInfo: The campground and all of its facilities are ADA compliant, except for the amphitheater, which has an unpaved, rocky trail leading to it. There is one ADA campsite, Site 30.

name: Hozomeen Campground
description: Hozomeen Campground is located at the north end of Ross Lake and is open from late May through October. There is no camping fee, and all sites are first-come, first-served. Facilities include boat launches, pit toilets, potable water, picnic tables and fire grates. Guests must pack-out all trash. Campsites located in the Upper Loop are closed until further notice due to hazard trees.
audioDescription: A forested campground near the shores of a reservoir.
reservationInfo: Campsites are first-come, first-served.
regulationsOverview: Do not feed or tease wildlife - keep your food and other appealing items in your vehicle at all times except when eating/using them. Pets must be on a leash or confined at all times. Tents must not be placed on or impact vegetation. Checkout time is 11:00 am on day of departure. Quiet hours are from 10 pm to 6 am. Camping is limited to no more than 14 days from July 1 to September 1 and no more than 30 days in a calendar year. Campfires in designated campfire rings only. No breaking off of trees or branches for wood.

fees.description: There is no camping fee.
fees.title: Hozomeen Campground Fees

directionsOverview: The only vehicle access to Hozomeen is via the Silver-Skagit Road, a 39-mile (62.4 km) gravel road leaving Highway 1 just three kilometers west of Hope, British Columbia (exit 168). The Silver Skagit road is graded at times, but washboards and potholes are common. Hozomeen has two graded cement boat ramps, which are generally accessible from mid-June through September.

images.title: Hozomeen Campground
images.altText: A wooded campsite with a picnic table and fire pit
images.caption: Hozomeen Campground

weatherOverview: The best weather for visiting the North Cascades generally occurs between mid-June and late September. Summer daytime temperatures average in the 70s F. Snow is off most trails by mid-July. Autumn and spring are popular for color and wildlife. Storms are common: always be prepared for a few days of rain and wind. The east side of the Cascade Mountains (Lake Chelan National Recreation Area) is drier and warmer in the summer than the west side. Summer temperatures at Stehekin reach the 90s F.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: No wheelchair accessible sites available.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Campfires are allowed within designated fire rings. Downed or dead wood may be collected. Firewood may be available for purchase from a private vendor nearby. Fire bans are common during summer months.
accessibility.rvInfo: Some campsites are suitable for trailers and RVs.
accessibility.adaInfo: No ADA sites available.
accessRoads: Unpaved Roads - All vehicles OK in good weather

name: Huckleberry Hill Hiker-Biker Campsite
description: Mile 62.0 - Hiker-biker campgrounds are located along the towpath approximately every 5-7 miles. No fee or reservation required. Overnight stays are limited to one night. All sites include a chemical toilet, picnic table, grill, and drinking water. Please Note: Potable water may not be available at each campsite. Water is treated with iodine. Please plan to have water purification tablets with you. Water is turned off from mid-November to mid-April each year.
audioDescription: (80 words) The nearest parking lots to Huckleberry Hill Campsite are either Harpers Ferry or Dargan Bend. The campsite is located between them. From Harpers Ferry you cross the Potomac River to the C&O Canal towpath. The campsite is located 2.1 miles upriver. From Dargan Bend Boat Ramp, the campsite is located 2.0 miles downriver on the towpath. A medium sized, narrow, grassy camping area between the Potomac River and the C&O towpath. There is a steep drop off to the river.

fees.description: First-come, first served.
fees.title: Walk-in, tent-only site

operatingHours.description: Campground is open year-round. Water is generally available from mid-April to mid-November.
operatingHours.name: Huckleberry Hill Hiker-Biker Overnight (HBO) Campsite

name: Huginnin Cove Campground
description: Huginnin Cove Campground is located at Huginnin Cove, on the north shore of Isle Royale National Park, off of the West and East Huginnin Cove Trails. Stay Limit: 3 consecutive nights from June 1  Labor Day annually. Access: Foot/canoe/kayak access. No dock available for boats.
audioDescription: The Huginnin Cove campground is located on Huginnin Cove, on the north west shore of Isle Royale National Park. The campground sits right on the rocky shore of Lake Superior. The Canadian shoreline can be viewed to the north. A rushing creek separates site one from the rest of the campground. Site one can be accessed via a foot bridge. Rocky coast is found on either side of the Huginnin Cove inlet. This backcountry campground includes five individual tent sites and vault toilets.
reservationInfo: Individual tent sites are first come, first serve.
regulationsOverview: All park visitors pay an entrance fee. Self-contained stoves only. Dogs, cats, and other pets are not allowed. Quiet hours are from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. EDT/ 9:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. CDT. Fishing licenses are not required for inland lakes and streams on the island. However, Michigan size, season, and possession limits still apply. Only barbless hooks and artificial lures and flies may be used on inland lakes and streams. A State of Michigan fishing license is required to fish in the waters of Lake Superior.

fees.description: No fee for small-party camping. A free overnight permit is required.
fees.title: Small-party Camping (6 people or less)

directionsOverview: Hugunnin Cove Campground is located at Hugunnin Cove on the north shore of Isle Royale National Park, off of the West and East Hugunnin Cove Trails.

operatingHours.description: The campground is open from April 16 - October 31 (the park operating season) annually, 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Hugunnin Cove Campground

images.title: View of Hugunnin Cove
images.altText: View of the blue waters of Hugunnin Cove with the shoreline of Canada in the distance.
images.caption: Hugunnin Cove Campground is a quaint location to camp on the north shore of Isle Royale National Park.

images.title: Sunset at Hugunnin Cove Campground
images.altText: Colorful sunset over Lake Superior at Hugunnin Cove Campground
images.caption: Hugunnin Cove Campground is an awesome location to watch sunsets.

images.title: Huginnin Cove Campground Tent Site #2
images.altText: Tent and camp chair looking through tress at Huginnin Cove of Lake Superior.
images.caption: Huginnin Cove is one of the few campgrounds along the north shore of Lake Superior.

weatherOverview: Isle Royale National Park is a remote archipelago in the middle of Lake Superior. To make the most of your visit, it is necessary that you plan ahead and prepare. Be aware that many services and items that are available on the mainland are not available at Isle Royale. Due to the unpredictable waters of Lake Superior and its effect on island weather, be prepared for any and all weather conditions.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: No wheelchair access.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Self-contained stoves only.
accessibility.rvInfo: No RV/Trailer access.
accessibility.adaInfo: Uneven, rough terrain throughout campground. Facilities are not accessible.

name: Hunters Campground
description: Hunters Campground is part of a larger recreation complex with a boat launch and Day Use Area. Campsites are tucked among the pines in a centrally-located loop with an easy walk to the beach area. Group sites offer privacy and beach access for larger parties. Hunters Campground is very popular and often busy in the summer.

passportStampImages.altText: A virtual passport stamp with an overview of the lake, with hills and trees surrounding it.
passportStampImages.title: Lake Roosevelt Virtual Visit 2022

reservationInfo: All sites are reservation only, year round.
regulationsOverview: Maximum Stay: Camping is limited to 14 consecutive nights per campground within a 30 day period and not more than 60 total nights per calendar year anywhere within LRNRA. These limits apply to all camping activities within LRNRA. Check-Out Time: Noon Quiet Hours: From 10 pm to 6 am. This includes generators. Nighttime Closures: Campgrounds are closed to non-registered campers from 10 pm to 6am. Site Occupation: All sites MUST be occupied each night. You may not pay for these sites and leave your belongings in them without nightly occupancy. Property left unattended for 24 hours will be considered abandoned. No more than two vehicles and ten people at each campsite. Leave No Trace: The wheels of all vehicles and trailers must be within the designated parking space and not on the roadway or vegetation. Do not attach wires, ropes, or nails to trees or shrubs. Digging, leveling, or other alterations of the ground is not permitted.

fees.description: The fee for an individual campsite per night from May 1 through September 30. Group size limit is 10 people and 2 vehicles.
fees.title: Standard Camping Fee, May 1  September 30

fees.description: Discounted camping rate for valid America the Beautiful Senior or Access passes. The fee for an individual campsite per night from May 1 through September 30. Group size limit is 10 people and 2 vehicles.
fees.title: Senior / Access Rate, May 1  September 30

fees.description: The fee for an individual campsite per night from October 1 through April 30. Group size limit is 10 people and 2 vehicles.
fees.title: Standard Camping Fee, October 1  April 30

fees.description: Discounted camping rate for valid America the Beautiful Senior or Access passes. The fee for an individual campsite per night from October 1 through April 30. Group size limit is 10 people and 2 vehicles.
fees.title: Senior / Access Rate, October 1  April 30

directionsOverview: From Fort Spokane, turn left onto US 25 North. Follow WA 25 approximately 20 miles north to the town of Hunters. In town, turn left at the Hunters Campground sign. Follow the Hunters Campground road about 2 miles to the campground.

operatingHours.description: Hunters is open year-round, but amenities like flush restrooms, water, and the dump station are not available in winter. They become available again when weather and lake water level allow.
operatingHours.name: Hunters Campground

images.title: Hunters Campground 1
images.altText: A broadly paved accessible campsite at Hunters Campground.
images.caption: An accessible campsite available at Hunters Campground.

images.title: Hunters Campground 2
images.altText: View of a campsite with paved parking, picnic table, and fire ring in the pines.
images.caption: A campsite at Hunters Campground.

images.title: Hunters Campground 3
images.altText: View across a small inlet to several campsites in the pines.
images.caption: Campsites in the pines at Hunters Campground with lake access.

weatherOverview: Summer weather is hot and buggy, with highs averaging in the 90s and lows in the 50s. Rain and thunderstorms can happen any time of year. In the winter, expect cold temperatures and possible snow. Temperatures can vary in spring and fall. Be prepared for many types of weather in all seasons.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Several campground restrooms are wheelchair accessible. All campground roads are paved, but footpaths between campsites are generally not wheelchair accessible. In the day use area, the covered picnic area is wheelchair accessible, but the swim beach is not. The boat launch parking area is wheelchair accessible.
accessibility.cellPhoneInfo: Cell service is spotty at Hunters Campground. Check or report cell reception on Recreation.gov campground reviews: https://www.recreation.gov/camping/campgrounds/10064730
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are permitted only in the designated fire rings, and only as long as there are no burn bans or dangerous fire weather.
accessibility.rvInfo: RVs and trailers up to 60 feet may camp at Hunters. Maximum vehicle length varies from site to site. Vehicles, trailers, or RVs cannot be parked on the grass or anywhere except the designated parking spot for each site. Hunters Campground does not have hookups.
accessibility.additionalInfo: Each campsite has a parking space, picnic table, and fire pit with grate. There is a boat launch (1232) with boat dock and parking area. There is a Day Use Area with fish-cleaning station, covered picnic area, and swim beach. Water and flush facilities are turned off during the winter and periods of extreme low water. Please check with us to be sure water is available.
accessibility.adaInfo: Campground roads and campsite parking spaces are paved. Campsite areas, such as picnic tables and fire pits, are unpaved and may be uneven. Site 3 is a designated ADA campsite. Restrooms have sidewalk pathways from the road.

name: Hunters Group Sites
description: The Hunters Group sites are part of a larger recreation complex with a boat launch and Day Use Area. The group sites are tucked among the pines on one side of the swim beach. An individual-site campground is located nearby. Hunters Campground is very popular and often busy in the summer.

passportStampImages.altText: A virtual passport stamp with an overview of the lake, with hills and trees surrounding it.
passportStampImages.title: Lake Roosevelt Virtual Visit 2022

reservationInfo: The Hunters group sites must be reserved year-round.
regulationsOverview: Maximum Stay: Camping is limited to 14 consecutive nights per campground within a 30 day period and not more than 60 total nights per calendar year anywhere within LRNRA. These limits apply to all camping activities within LRNRA. Check-Out Time: Noon Quiet Hours: From 10 pm to 6 am. This includes generators. Nighttime Closures: Campgrounds are closed to non-registered campers from 10 pm to 6am. Site Occupation: No more 25 people per group site. Property left unattended for 24 hours will be considered abandoned. Leave No Trace: The wheels of all vehicles and trailers must be within the designated parking space and not on the roadway or vegetation. Do not attach wires, ropes, or nails to trees or shrubs. Digging, leveling, or other alterations of the ground is not permitted.

fees.description: The fee for a group site with 1  25 occupants.
fees.title: Group Camping Fee, 1  25 People

directionsOverview: From Fort Spokane, turn left onto US 25 North. Follow WA 25 approximately 20 miles north to the town of Hunters. In town, turn left at the Hunters Campground sign. Follow the Hunters Campground road about 2 miles to the campground.

operatingHours.description: Hunters Group sites are open year-round, but amenities like flush restrooms, water, and the dump station are not available in winter.  They become available again when weather and lake water level allow.
operatingHours.name: Hunters Group Sites

images.title: Hunters Group Site
images.altText: Log parking bumpers are lined up along the grassy edge of Hunters Group Site with tall pines beyond.
images.caption: An overview of a group site with the lakeshore beyond.

images.title: Hunters Group Site - Lakeshore
images.altText: Picnic tables nestled against the pine trees with a lakeshore view beyond.
images.caption: Have a picnic with a great view!

images.title: Hunters Group Site - Parking & Restroom
images.altText: Paved parking areas, log grass bumpers, and an accessible vault toilet building beyond.
images.caption: Parking at the Hunters Group Site with accessible vault toilets.

weatherOverview: Summer weather is hot and buggy, with highs averaging in the 90s and lows in the 50s. Rain and thunderstorms can happen any time of year. In the winter, expect cold temperatures and possible snow. Temperatures can vary in spring and fall. Be prepared for many types of weather in all seasons.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: The nearby Day Use Area restrooms are wheelchair accessible. All campground roads are paved. The campground boat launch parking area is paved. Access to the swim beach is not wheelchair accessible.
accessibility.cellPhoneInfo: Cell service is spotty at Hunters Campground. Check or report cell reception on Recreation.gov campground reviews: https://www.recreation.gov/camping/campgrounds/234068
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are permitted only in the designated fire rings, and only as long as there are no burn bans or dangerous fire weather.
accessibility.rvInfo: RVs and trailers may camp at Hunters. Vehicles, trailers, or RVs cannot be parked on the grass or anywhere except the designated parking spot for each site. Hunters Campground does not have hookups.
accessibility.additionalInfo: There is a boat launch (1232) with boat dock and parking area. There is a Day Use Area with fish-cleaning station, covered picnic area, and swim beach. Water and flush facilities are turned off during the winter and periods of extreme low water. Please check with us to be sure water is available.
accessibility.adaInfo: The campground access road is paved, the group site parking areas are packed gravel. Campsite areas, like picnic tables and fire pits, are unpaved.

name: Hurricane River Campground
description: There are two loops: 11 campsites in the lower loop and ten in the upper loop. Both loops include one disabled accessible campsite. Several campsites are designated as generator-free. Because the turning radius and some parking site lengths are limited within this campground, we recommend single vehicles no more than 36 feet and vehicle/trailer combined length no more than 42 feet. The campground is open by reservation only, mid-May through mid-October. Closed the rest of the year.
reservationInfo: All campsites/campgrounds require reservations year-round. To reserve a site, go to www.recreation.gov or call 1-877-444-6777. International callers: (606) 515-6777. Reservation line (TDD): (877) 833-6777 Wi-Fi is available at the Munising Falls Visitor Center (year round) and Grand Sable Visitor Center (summer only). Cell service usually can be picked up in Munising and Grand Marais.
regulationsOverview: Camping is limited to 14 days per year within the park. Quiet hours are 8 pm to 8 am. This includes generator use. Music should be for private listening only. Check out time is 11 am. Pets must be on a 6 ft or less leash at all times. 1-2 vehicles per site, including towed trailers. They must be parked within the delineated campsite parking slot. No more than 8 people per site. No more than 2 tents or hammocks per site. One tent must be placed on the tent pad and the second placed within 6 ft of the pad. A screened tent may be placed over the picnic table. Campfires are permitted in fire rings only. Do not leave fires unattended. No firewood collecting in campground. Do not hang lanterns from trees. Do not put nails in trees. Food & odors attract bears! ALL food, beverages, cooking equipment, toiletries, food containers, and pet food MUST be locked in a hard-sided vehicle at any time - DAY or NIGHT - when not in immediate use. Garbage must be placed in trash cans. Violation may result in a fine.

fees.description: Overnight fee $25.00  Holders of the America The Beautiful Senior Pass (62 and older) and the America The Beautiful Access Pass (disabled) receive a 50% discount.
fees.title: Hurricane River Campground Camping Fee - mid May to mid October

directionsOverview: Hurricane River campground is located 12 miles west of Grand Marais on County Road H-58

operatingHours.description: All park campsites require a reservation, which is obtained through www.recreation.gov. Campgrounds may be used year round. Winter access is usually snowmobile or ski-in access only. Roads are not plowed. See the camping page on this website for more information.
operatingHours.name: Hurricane River Campground

addresses.line1: 11.2 miles west of Grand Marais on H-58
11.2 miles west of Grand Marais on H-58

images.title: Hurricane River Campground
images.altText: Campsite, including tent and picnic table in forest setting.
images.caption: Hurricane River campsite

images.title: Hurricane River Campground Map
images.altText: Map of Hurricane River campground showing site numbers, vault toilets, and water.
images.caption: Campsite Map for Upper and Lower Hurricane River campground

weatherOverview: The park drive-in campgrounds close in mid-October due to the potential for freezing at this time.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Wheelchairs may have difficulty moving around the campground. The campground is rustic, with dirt camping pads and pathways. The vault toilets are on cement pads. Accessible sites include packed gravel or wooden boardwalk at the site, a raised fire ring, and cooking grill mounted on a post.
accessibility.cellPhoneInfo: Sometimes cell service can be picked up near the Au Sable Lightstation. Cell service is pretty good near the Grand Sable Visitor Center.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Metal campfire rings with grill grates are available at each campsite in the lakeshore's drive-in campgrounds. Keep your fire in the fire ring provided. If there is no fire ring, fires are prohibited. Collecting wood in the campground is prohibited. Buy firewood locally. Keep your fire small. Never leave a fire burning when you leave the site. Dowse it with water. Beach fires are prohibited. To prevent the potential spread of emerald ash borer, ash firewood is banned in Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore. Ash firewood is a carrier for the emerald ash borer, a small exotic insect that has infested ash trees in many parts of the country.
accessibility.rvInfo: Because turning radius and parking site lengths are limited within this campground, we recommend single vehicles no more than 36 feet and vehicle/trailer combined length no more than 42 feet.
accessibility.adaInfo: Wheelchair accessible campsites are available at each campground and can be reserved on www.recreaton.gov. The park's campgrounds are rustic and do not have electric, telephone, water, or sewer hookups. Typically there is no cell phone reception. The vault toilets are on cement pads. The campground is rustic, with dirt camping pads and pathways. Campground quiet hours are 8 pm to 8 am (this applies to generators as well).
accessRoads: Unpaved Roads - All vehicles OK in good weather

name: Igloo Creek
description: Igloo Creek Campground is at mile 35 on the Park Road. It offers 7 sites, making it the smallest in Denali (along with Sanctuary River Campground, which also has 7 sites). Igloo is tent-onlyyou will not find any RVs or other vehicles in this campground. It is accessible only by camper bus. The bus stop is a short walk from the campsites (less than 50 yards).
reservationInfo: Reservations are strongly recommended. Group campsites are not available at Igloo; larger groups of 920 people should consider staying at Riley Creek or Savage River Campgrounds.

fees.description: This is the cost to stay per night at Igloo Creek Campground. You may stay up to 14 total nights in a given summer. Three tents and up to eight people may use a single site.
fees.title: Nightly Fee

directionsOverview: This campground can only be reached by bus. Be sure to book a camper bus ticket when purchasing a stay at Igloo Creek Campground.

operatingHours.description: Check in / check out time for the campground is 11 am. You do not need to leave the park by 11 am - just be sure to have your campsite packed up by that time. Igloo is open in summer only (see exceptions, below, for when the campground will close each fall).
operatingHours.name: Igloo Creek

images.title: Igloo Welcoming Committee
images.altText: two brown bears scratching at a large wooden sign that reads "Igloo Creek Campground"
images.caption: While many visitors do not see bears at Igloo Campground, remember that you are camping in bear country.

images.title: Camping at Igloo
images.altText: two people sitting in chairs outside of their tent in a forest
images.caption: Igloo Campground is in the middle of Igloo Forest, which is mainly made up of spruce trees.

images.title: Igloo Creek Campground
images.altText: person sitting near an orange tent
images.caption: Campsites in Igloo Creek have some brush screening between sites.

images.title: Filling water at Igloo Creek
images.altText: a woman filtering water into a plastic bottle from a shallow creek
images.caption: Igloo Creek has no well or water tap. Water must be gathered from the nearby creek, so bring a filter.

images.title: Igloo Creek Food Locker
images.altText: a woman placing food into a large metal locker
images.caption: Food lockers at Igloo Creek ensure that wildlife cannot steal your food. Keep all scented items (e.g., deodorant, toothpaste) in the locker, not just your food.

images.title: Relaxing at Igloo Creek Campground
images.altText: A grizzly on its hind legs leaning on a large wooden sign that reads "Igloo Creek Campground"
images.caption: Keep in mind that bears can be found nearly anywhere in Denali. Keep your food and other scented items stored properly in the campground facilities provided!

images.title: Covered Shelter
images.altText: picnic tables covered by a wall-less, roofed enclosure in a forest
images.caption: A covered eating area is available at Igloo Creek Campground

images.title: Restrooms at Igloo
images.altText: wooden building with two doors in a forest
images.caption: Igloo has two pit toilets for campers.

weatherOverview: We recommend you bring a sleeping bag rated to 20 degrees F. Expect rain, though sunny days do occur periodically throughout the summer. Highs are usually in the 60s, though sometimes can reach the low 80s. Snow is possible any month of the year, however.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Restrooms are wheelchair accessible.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Open fires are prohibited. Please bring a cook stove to prepare your meals.
accessibility.rvInfo: This is a tent-only campground.
accessibility.additionalInfo: All campgrounds have recycling collection containers for aluminum cans, glass, plastic jugs and bottles (#1 and #2), and plastic containers #5.
accessibility.adaInfo: Surfaces in the campground are largely compacted gravel or native soils with roots and rocks. The path from the campground to the bus stop on the Denali Park Road is compacted gravel. Restrooms are wheelchair accessible.

name: Indian Cove Campground
description: Indian Cove Campground is located off of Highway 62, thirteen miles east of Joshua Tree Village and ten miles west of Twentynine Palms on the north side of the Wonderland of Rocks. Indian Cove Road dead-ends at this secluded area. Indian Cove has 101 campsites, including thirteen group campsites. Between Memorial Day and Labor Day it is 39 reservable sites. There are vault toilets but no water at the campsites. Water is available at the small ranger station roughly two miles north of the campground.
audioDescription: Indian Cove Campground is a desert campground nestled among rocky outcrops and mountains. The campground is made up of a mix of paved and dirt roads making several loops with camping spots to accommodate tents and RVs. Each camping spot has a dirt parking area, picnic table, fire pit, and campsite marker. The ground is hard and rocky. Throughout the campground there are many Joshua trees, small trees, and shrubs. Scattered around the campground you can find trash and recycling cans, bathrooms, and a couple of trailheads.
reservationInfo: Reservations are required year-round and can be made up to six months in advance. Book a site at www.recreation.gov or by calling 877-444-6777.
regulationsOverview: A maximum of six people, three tents, and two vehicles may occupy an individual campsite, if there is space. A vehicle towing a trailer, popup, tent trailer, or fifth wheel, or a motorhome towing a vehicle, is considered two vehicles. Camping fees must be paid within one hour of selecting a campsite. Check in and check out are at noon. There is a 30-day camping limit each year. Only 14 of these nights may take place from October-May. All tents, tarps, and other camping equipment must be set up within 25 feet (7.6 m) of the picnic table or fire grate. Food must be stored securely where wildlife cannot get to it. Any scented or odorous items, including sunscreen and toiletries, must be secured as if they were food. Campsites left vacant for 24 hours will be treated as vacant. Holding or reserving campsites for persons not present is not allowed. Pets must remain on leash at all times and may not be left unattended. No slacklines in campgrounds.

fees.description: Camping fees must be paid within one hour of selecting a campsite. A maximum of six people, three tents, and two cars may occupy an individual campsite, only if there is space available. Some sites only have enough parking for one vehicle.
fees.title: Individual Campsite at Indian Cove

fees.description: There are 13 Group Campsites at Indian Cove Campground. The cost is $35-50 depending on the site capactiy. These group sites can accommodate RVs or trailers, but maximum combined length can be no more than 25 feet.
fees.title: Group Campsite at Indian Cove

fees.description: Nightly camping fee for one site for a camper with a Senior or Access pass. Camping fees must be paid within one hour of selecting a campsite. A maximum of six people, three tents, and two cars may occupy an individual campsite, only if there is space available. Some sites only have enough parking for one vehicle.
fees.title: Senior/Access Pass Individual Campsite at Indian Cove

fees.description: Nightly camping fee for one site for a camper with a Senior or Access pass. There are 13 Group Campsites at Indian Cove Campground. The cost is $17.50-25 depending on the site capacity. These group sites can accommodate RVs or trailers, but maximum combined length can be no more than 25 feet.
fees.title: Senior/Access Group Campsite at Indian Cove

operatingHours.description: Campgrounds are open 24 hours a day. Check in and check out are at noon. Quiet hours are from 10:00 pm to 6:00 am.
operatingHours.name: Indian Cove Campground

images.title: Indian Cove Entrance Station
images.altText: A sign that reads 'Joshua Tree National Park... Indian Cove'. Behind it is a building.
images.caption: The entrance station at Indian Cove Campground. You can pay the camping fee and get water here.

images.title: Restrooms at Indian Cove
images.altText: A paved path leading to a small vault toilet.
images.caption: Indian Cove Campground has no running water around the campsites but there are vault toilets available.

images.title: Indian Cove Campground
images.altText: Looking down on Indian Cove Campground with the road, a vault toilet and campsites.
images.caption: Indian Cove Campground lies amid the huge, steep rock formations for which Joshua Tree National Park is known.

images.title: Amphitheater at Indian Cove
images.altText: Rows of seats and a stage surrounded by a large rock formation.
images.caption: Indian Cove has an amphitheater for ranger programs and talks.

images.title: Indian Cove Group Campsite
images.altText: Several tents and picnic tables lit up in the evening in front of large rock formations.
images.caption: One of Indian Cove Campground's group sites.

weatherOverview: Days are typically clear with less than 25% humidity. Temperatures are most comfortable in the spring and fall, with an average high/low of 85 and 50F (29 and 10C) respectively. Winter brings cooler days, around 60F (15C), and freezing nights. It occasionally snows at higher elevations. Summers are hot, over 100F (38C) during the day and may cool to around 75F (24C) at night. Weather can change quickly. Check a weather forecast before camping.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Most roads and paths are unpaved and uneven.
accessibility.cellPhoneInfo: Cell phone service is spotty and unreliable.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Because of the park's very dry climate, fire danger in Joshua Tree is almost always very high. Be cautious. Campfires are allowed only in designated fire rings or grills that are found in park campgrounds or picnic areas. Keep fires small. Bring your own firewood. You may not gather park vegetation, whether living or dead, to fuel your campfire. If you plan to have a campfire, bring extra water to douse it thoroughly.
accessibility.rvInfo: There are no hookups for RVs at any campground in Joshua Tree. Generator use is permitted only from 7:00-9:00 am, 12:00-2:00 pm, and 5:00-7:00 pm.
accessibility.additionalInfo: There is potable water near the entrance and fee station to the campground, but none in the campground.
accessibility.adaInfo: There are no ADA accessible campsites in Indian Cove Campground. If you are looking to reserve an ADA accessible campsites please look into Jumbo Rocks Campground, site 122 and Black Rock Campground, site 61 which are ADA accessible.
accessRoads: Unpaved Roads - All vehicles OK in good weather

name: Indian Creek Campground
description: CLOSED FOR 2022. Located about eight miles south of Mammoth Hot Springs on the road to Norris, Indian Creek Campgroundelevation 7,300 feet (2225 m)sits near the base of the Gallatin Mountains and offers breathtaking views of Electric Peak. The area offers easy access to fishing and hiking. The campground is away from the main road and provides a quieter, more primitive, experience than many other locations. This is a reservable campground run by the National Park Service.
reservationInfo: All sites are reservable on Recreation.gov. Eighty percent of sites are reservable six months in advance, while the remaining 20% of sites are available two weeks in advance.
regulationsOverview: Overnight camping or parking is only allowed in designated campgrounds or campsites. Campsite occupancy is limited to six people per site. Checkout time is 10 am. Camping is limited to 14 days from July 1 through Labor Day, and 30 days for the rest of the year. There is no stay limit at the Fishing Bridge RV Park. Unless posted otherwise, wood and charcoal fires are permitted in all campgrounds except the Fishing Bridge RV Park. Propane grills and stoves are usually unaffected by fire restrictions. All odorous items that may attract bears, including food, cooking gear, toiletries, and garbage, must be kept secured when not in use. Bear-proof storage boxes are available at many campsites. Where permitted, generators may only be operated from 8 am to 8 pm (60 dB limit). Generators are not permitted at Indian Creek, Lewis Lake, Pebble Creek, Slough Creek, or Tower Fall.

fees.description: Interagency Access and Senior Pass holders receive a 50% discount.
fees.title: Nightly Fee

fees.description: This is the per-person cost for a hiker/bicyclist campsite for one night.
fees.title: Hiker/bicyclist Night Fee

directionsOverview: Located on the Grand Loop Road between Mammoth Hot Springs and Norris.

operatingHours.description: The campground is typically only open during summer. Checkout time is 10 am. See exceptions for exact dates of operation.
operatingHours.name: Indian Creek Campground

images.caption: All campgrounds in Yellowstone including Indian Creek Campground is in bear country.

weatherOverview: Yellowstone's weather can vary greatly within a day and throughout the park. Snow can fall every month of the year. Summer highs reach 7080F (2530C) during the day, but nights can be cool (and it may freeze at higher elevations). During spring and fall, daytime highs range from 3060F (020C), with overnight lows below freezing.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Paths in the campground area are compacted gravel/dirt with limited gradient change.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Wood and charcoal fires are permitted in this campground, though special fire restrictions are occasionally put in place when the danger of wildland fires is great. If you plan to light a fire in the park, please ask about current fire restrictions at the entrance station when you arrive. Propane grills and stoves are normally not restricted.
accessibility.rvInfo: 10 sites at 35 feet (10.7 m), 35 sites at 30 feet (9.1 m). Sites may not be level.
accessibility.additionalInfo: No recycling being collected at this campground.
accessibility.adaInfo: Two accessible campsites; accessible vault toilet adjacent to campsites.

name: Indian Flats Hiker-Biker Campsite
description: Mile 42.5 - Hiker-biker campgrounds are located along the towpath approximately every 5-7 miles. No fee or reservation required. Overnight stays are limited to one night. All sites include a chemical toilet, picnic table, grill, and drinking water. Please Note: Potable water may not be available at each campsite. Water is treated with iodine. Please plan to have water purification tablets with you. Water is turned off from mid-November to mid-April each year.
audioDescription: (55 words) The nearest parking to Indian Flats Hiker-Biker Campsite is a the Monocacy Aqueduct. From the parking lot, walk toward the Aqueduct and towpath. Turn right at the towpath, heading upriver on the Aqueduct. In .3 miles on your left is a medium sized, wooded, rolling camping area between the Potomac River and the C&O towpath.

fees.description: First-come, first served.
fees.title: Walk-in, tent-only site

operatingHours.description: Campground is open year-round. Water is generally available from mid-April to mid-November.
operatingHours.name: Indian Flats Hiker-Biker Overnight (HBO) Campsite

images.title: Indian Flats Hiker-Biker Campsite
images.altText: A small campsite tucked in the trees with a picnic table and firepit.
images.caption: Indian Flats Hiker-Biker Campsite

name: Indian Well Campground
description: Lava Beds has one campground, Indian Well Campground, located 1/2 mile (0.8 km) from the Visitor Center and cave loop. There are 43 sites available on a first-come, first serve basis. Sites can accommodate tents, pickup campers, small trailers and motor homes up to 30 feet. Note: not all sites can accommodate motor homes.
reservationInfo: The only site that can be reserved is the group site. To reserve the group site call 530-667-8113, groups must have at least 15 people with a max of 40.
regulationsOverview: Quiet hours are from 9:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. and all campground rules apply to groups. Maximum 8 persons per site, 2 vehicles or 3 motorcycles Maximum stay is 14 consecutive days in a 30-day period Holders of an Access or Senior pass receive a 50% discount on their site Pets are permitted in the campground, but must be on a leash no longer than 6 feet (1.8 m) Pets are not permitted in caves, trails or in buildings.

fees.description: Sites are $10 per night, per site, and include a picnic table fire ring and cooking grill. Quiet hours are from 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. and all campground rules apply to groups. Maximum 8 persons per site, 2 vehicles or 3 motorcycles. Maximum stay is 14 consecutive days in a 30-day period. Holders of an Access or Senior pass receive a 50% discount on their site. Pets are permitted in the campground, but must be on a leash no longer than 6 feet (1.8 m) Pets are not permitted in caves, trails or in buildings.
fees.title: Camping fee

directionsOverview: Indian Well Campground is located 1/2 mile (0.8 km) from the Visitor Center and cave loop.

operatingHours.description:
Lava Beds has one campground, Indian Well Campground, located 1/2 mile (0.8 km) from the visitor center and cave loop. There are 43 sites available on a first-come, first serve basis. Sites can accommodate tents, pickup campers, small trailers and motor homes up to 30 feet. Note: not all sites can accommodate motor homes. PLEASE NOTE: Loop B closes for the winter after the Thanksgiving holiday.

Sites are $10 per night, per site, and include a picnic table fire ring and cooking grill.
operatingHours.name: Indian Well Campground

images.title: Campsite
images.altText: Campsite
images.caption: Campsite in A Loop

weatherOverview: Park elevations range from 4,000 to 5,700 feet. Cold weather is possible any time of year, and snow has been recorded in all months. Winter daytime highs average 40F; lows average 20F. Morning fog is frequent from autumn through spring. Summer daytime highs average 75 to 80F; lows average 50F. Occasional thunderstorms occur in summer.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: The two ADA campsites have paved surfaces that provide wheelchair access to the picnic tables, camp stove, and water spigots. The campground roads are paved with sloped sidewalks allowing easy access to restrooms, drinking fountains and the amphitheater.
accessibility.internetInfo: WIFI is available at the visitor center.
accessibility.cellPhoneInfo: Cell phone reception is spotty, and is sometimes better at the visitor center.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Wood fires are permitted inside fire rings unless otherwise posted. Camp stoves are also permitted.
accessibility.rvInfo: The campgrounds is designed primarily for tent camping but small (less than 35 ft long) RV and trailers can be accommodated at a few sites.
accessibility.adaInfo: There are two campsites that are designated as ADA camp sites. There are also ADA restrooms in both the A and B loops of the campgrounds and a paved trail to the paved amphitheater.

name: Indigo Neck Hiker-Biker Campsite
description: Mile 139.2 - No fee charged. First come, first served. Stay is limited to one night per site, per trip. Campground has a chemical toilet, water, a picnic table, and grill. Please Note: Potable water may not be available at each campsite. Water is treated with iodine. Please plan to have water purification tablets with you. Water is turned off from November 15 to April 15 each year.
audioDescription: (65 words) The nearest parking is at the Fifteenmile Creek Drive-in campsite. The towpath is on the northern edge of the parking lot. Turn right and head downriver on the towpath for about 1.7 miles. The Indigo Neck Hiker-Biker Campsite is a small, flat, narrow, lightly wooded site. It is bordered by the Potomac River and the towpath. Lock 57 is adjacent to it. End of description.
reservationInfo: First come, first served

fees.description: First come, first served
fees.title: Walk-in, tent-only site

operatingHours.description: Campground is open year-round. Water is generally available from mid-April to mid-November.
operatingHours.name: Indigo Neck Hiker Biker Overnight (HBO) Campsite

images.title: Indigo Neck Hiker-Biker Campsite
images.altText: A trail leads to a grassy campsite in the trees.
images.caption: Indigo Neck Hiker-Biker Campsite

weatherOverview: Campsites are located in close proximity to the Potomac River and are subject to flooding after heavy rain.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: Gravel, uneven terrain
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are restricted to the grills and fire rings provided or to portable grills positioned off the ground. Coals must be extinguished and removed from the park. Firewood may be collected from dead material on the ground but for use in campgrounds only. Do not remove wood from the campground. Firewood cannot be brought into the park.
accessibility.rvInfo: N/A
accessibility.adaInfo: Not ADA accessible

name: Intermediate Lake Campground
description: Intermediate Lake Campground is located on the shoreline of Intermediate Lake. Intermediate Lake can be accessed via a .6 mile portage from Lake Richie or a .4 mile portage from Siskiwit Lake. Stay Limit: 2 nights effective June 1  Labor Day annually. Access: Canoe/kayak, no private boat access.
audioDescription: Intermediate Lake Campground is located on the shoreline of Intermediate Lake. Consecutive night stay limit is two nights. Three individual tent sites are available. Intermediate Lake can be accessed via a .6 mile portage from Lake Richie or a .4 mile portage from Siskiwit Lake. No boat access. Canoe/kayak access.
reservationInfo: Individual tent sites are first come, first serve.
regulationsOverview: All park visitors pay an entrance fee. Self-contained stoves only. Dogs, cats, and other pets are not allowed. Quiet hours are from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. EDT/ 9:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. CDT. Fishing licenses are not required for inland lakes and streams on the island. However, Michigan size, season, and possession limits still apply. Only barbless hooks and artificial lures and flies may be used on inland lakes and streams. A State of Michigan fishing license is required to fish in the waters of Lake Superior.

fees.description: No fee for small-party camping. A free overnight permit is required.
fees.title: Small-party Camping (6 people or less)

directionsOverview: Intermediate Lake Campground is located on the shoreline of Intermediate Lake.

operatingHours.description: The campground is open from April 16 - October 31 (the park operating season) annually, 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Intermediate Lake Campground

images.title: Intermediate Lake by Canoe
images.altText: Calm waters of a small lake greet the bow of an overturned canoe with paddles resting against it.
images.caption: Intermediate Lake is a small lake between Lake Richie and Siskiwit Lake

weatherOverview: Isle Royale National Park is a remote archipelago in the middle of Lake Superior. To make the most of your visit, it is necessary that you plan ahead and prepare. Be aware that many services and items that are available on the mainland are not available at Isle Royale. Due to the unpredictable waters of Lake Superior and its effect on island weather, be prepared for any and all weather conditions.

accessibility.wheelchairAccess: No wheelchair access.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Self-contained stoves only.
accessibility.rvInfo: No RV/Trailer access.
accessibility.adaInfo: Uneven, rough terrain throughout campground. Facilities are not accessible.

name: Irons Mountain Hiker-Biker Campsite
description: Mile 175.3 - No fee charged; this is a first-come first served walk in campsite. Stay is limited to one night per site, per trip. Campground has a chemical toilet, water, a picnic table, and grill. Please Note: Potable water may not be available at each campsite. Water is treated with iodine. Please plan to have water purification tablets with you. Water is turned off from November 15 to April 15 each year.

fees.description: First-come, first served.
fees.title: Walk-in, tent-only site

operatingHours.description: Campground is open year-round. Water is generally available from mid-April to mid-November.
operatingHours.name: Iron's Mountain Hiker-Biker Overnight (HBO) Campsite

images.title: Irons Mountain Hiker-Biker Campsite
images.altText: A grass covered campsite
images.caption: Irons Mountain Hiker-Biker Campsite

weatherOverview: Campsites are near the Potomac River and are subject to flooding after heavy rains.

accessibility.cellPhoneInfo: Cell phone reception is spotty throughout the park and is dependent on the carrier.
accessibility.fireStovePolicy: Fires are restricted to the grills and fire rings provided or to portable grills positioned off the ground. Coals must be extinguished and removed from the park. Firewood may be collected from dead material on the ground but for use in campgrounds only. Do not remove wood from the campground. Firewood cannot be brought into the park.

name: Island Mine Campground
description: Island Mine Campground is located .5 miles south from the junction of the Greenstone and Island Mine Trails, on the Island Mine Trail. This inland campground offers no canoe/kayak/boat access. Little Siskiwit River runs south of the campground, where water can usually be obtained for filtering, unless it is dried up. Check with a Visitor Center for current water status. Stay Limit: 3 nights effective June 1  Labor Day annually. Access: Foot
audioDescription: Island Mine Campground is located on the western side of Isle Royale National Park. It is located on the Island Mine Trail that connects the Greenstone Ridge Trail to Siskiwit Bay Campground. This backcountry campground includes four individual tent sites, two group tent sites, and vault toilets. Island Mine Campground sits in a sugar maple forest and is colorful during the fall. The campground sits upon a small ridge with gently flowing creeks on either side. The main water source is a creek on the south end of the campground. Southeast of Island Mine Campground is the historic Island Mine that was last active in 1870. Remnants of humans exploring copper resources are a steam engine, mining rubble, a dried out well and a cemetery off in the woods.
reservationInfo: Individual tent sites are first come, first serve. Group tent sites must be reserved in advance.
regulationsOverview: All park visitors pay an entrance fee. Campfire rings or standing grills provided. Dogs, cats, and other pets are not allowed. Quiet hours are from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. EDT/ 9:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. CDT. Fishing licenses are not required for inland lakes and streams on the island. However, Michigan size, season, and possession limits still apply. Only barbless hooks and artificial lures and flies may be used on inland lakes and streams. A State of Michigan fishing license is required to fish in the waters of Lake Superior.

fees.description: No fee for small-party camping. A free overnight permit is required.
fees.title: Small-party Camping (6 people or less)

fees.description: 2 Group Sites by advanced reservation only. All parties of 7 or more must submit group permit requests through the park's online request system. The fee is a per permit cost for each party within a group of 7 or more.
fees.title: Group Tent Sites

directionsOverview: The Island Mine Campground is located .5 miles south of the Greenstone and Island Mine Trails junction, off of the Island Mine Trail.

operatingHours.description: The campground is open from April 16 - October 31 (the park operating season) annually, 24 hours a day.
operatingHours.name: Island Mine Campground
